Contrary to the analysis of the EXAFS spectra, which is done by properly fitting the experimental spectrum in a path-by-path fashion, the analysis of NEXAFS spectra is not trivial. Four approaches are generally applied: (i) direct comparison of the spectra with those from reference compounds, (ii) linear combination of spectra of known compounds, (iii) fitting using a number of peak functions to determine the position and intensity of NEXAFS resonances, and (iv) simulation using full multiple scattering procedures. In all the above cases, prior to analysis, the NEXAFS spectra should be subjected to subtraction of a linear background and normalization to the edge jump or the atomic limit as described in Fig. 4.6. In case (i) the spectra of the studied compounds are directly compared with spectra of reference compounds, e.g., oxides, metal foils, etc. The first derivative of the spectra can be also compared, while in some cases the difference spectrum is also provided. For example, the difference spectrum is used in X-ray magnetic circular dichroism (XMCD) where the XANES spectra of magnetic materials, usually recorded in the L 2,3 edges of a transition metal, using left and right circularly polarized SR beam are subtracted from each other [50]. In another application the difference spectra are obtained from the NEXAFS spectra recorded at different angles of incidence [51]. An important piece of information that can be derived from the NEXAFS spectra is the oxidation state of the absorbing atom which is deduced from the chemical shift of the absorption edge. Higher oxidation states result in a blue shift of the absorption edge, which usually indicates a smaller bond length. An example of the chemical shift of the absorption edge in Fe-containing compounds is shown in Fig. 4.8. The position of the absorption edge can be determined from the maximum of the first derivative. In approach (ii) the spectra of multiphase materials are simulated as a weighted average of spectra from reference compounds. This method is applicable due to the localized character of XANES which is mainly dominated from the small photoelectron mean free path. An example of the linear combination fitting (sometimes it is referred to as principal component analysis) of Pd-K-edge XANES spectra from a Pd-doped polymer adopted from [52] is shown in Fig. 4.9.
Approach (iii) is applied when the XANES spectrum is considered proportional to the density of empty states in the conduction band, or to antibonding molecular orbital states, or even when information should be extracted from pre-edge peaks that appear in the spectra recorded at the K-edge of transition metals. An example of fitting of a C-K-edge XANES spectrum of the polymer poly(2,5-bis (3-tetradecylthiophen-2-yl)thieno-[3,2-b] thiophene) [PBTTT] adopted from Ref. [53] is shown in Fig. 4.10. The NEXAFS spectrum is fitted with a step function and a number of Gaussians. The step function accounts for the transitions from the initial 1s state to final states in the continuum. In this case the C atom is ionized and the photoelectron may have any kinetic energy. Peak functions are used to account for transitions from the initial 1s state to a final bound empty state of an antibonding molecular orbital. Such states, which result from the formation of covalent bonds, are strongly directional and result in strong localization of the electron charge in the interatomic space. Gaussian functions are used when the experimental broadening, related to the energy resolution of the monochromator, is larger than the natural width of the transition, denoted with Γ. It is determined as Γ ' ħ=τ, where τ is the transition lifetime defined by 1=τ ¼ 1=τ e þ 1=τ h , τ h and τ e are the lifetimes of the initial state (core-hole lifetime) and the final state of the electron. Although the latter is very high, the core-hole lifetime is generally much smaller and decreases with the atomic number of the absorbing atom, thus resulting in sharp NEXAFS features in the K-edge spectra of low-Z elements, e.g., B, C, N, O etc. [13,54]. Gaussian functions are also used when the samples are highly disordered. When the natural broadening dominates the experimental one, Lorentzian functions are used, whereas when the natural and experimental broadening is comparable, Voigt functions (convolution of a Gaussian and a Lorentzian) can be used.
Additional valuable information on the geometry of the polyhedron formed around transition metal atoms (Fe, Mn, Co, V, Cr, etc.) as well as on their oxidation state can be obtained from the fitting of the pre-edge peaks that appear in their K-edge spectra. The pre-edge peak corresponds to transitions from the 1s initial state to a final (empty) d-state. Although such a transition is forbidden due to the Δ' ¼ AE1 selection rule in the dipole approximation, it gains intensity due to the p-d hybridization that is induced by the modification of the metal crystal field by its ligands. An example of a pre-edge peak fitting is shown in Fig. 4.11 [55]. The pre-edge peaks were recorded in the micro-XANES mode (with capillary optics and a beam diameter of 5 μm) at the Fe-K-edge from different spots of a sample with inhomogeneous distribution of Fe. In regions with low Fe concentration, the pre-edge peak was sharp and intense and could be fitted with one Lorentzian function. Contrary to that, the pre-edge peak recorded from Fe-rich regions is broader and with lower intensity and can be fitted with two or more Voigt functions. Furthermore, redshifts of the pre-edge peak centroid indicate reduction of the oxidation state of the absorbing atom. Extended discussions on the fitting process and the information that can be extracted from the pre-edge peak of Fe and Mn can be found in Refs. [56][57][58].
The approach (iv) in the analysis of the XANES spectra, i.e., the simulation using proper software, is generally more difficult and time-consuming. The simulations necessitate the use of a structural model, i.e., Cartesian coordinates of the atoms that comprise a cluster around the absorbing atom, which is either provided by other characterization techniques, e.g., diffraction techniques in crystalline materials or by theoretical calculations, e.g., molecular dynamics [49]. Despite the complexity of this method, the significance of multiple scattering contributions in the XANES spectra provides a sensitive tool in the local bonding geometry since the XANES spectra of structural polymorphs, which are hardly distinguishable by EXAFS, are considerably different [13,51]. Full multiple scattering calculations prevail in the simulation of the XANES spectra due to their applicability in materials that lack long-range periodicity and take into account effects such as core hole and inelastic losses. Examples of simulations of XANES spectra using the FEFF code are shown in Fig. 4.12 (Zn-K-edge) and Fig. 4.13 (N-K-edge).
Among the abovementioned procedures, fitting of the spectrum with step function(s) and a number of peak functions permits (i) the quantification of defects from defectrelated states [61], (ii) the quantification of charge transfer from the intensity of "white lines" assigned to transitions to final states strongly localized on the absorbing atom [62], (iii) the determination of the different contributions in the magnetic moments from the XMCD spectra (Sect. 6.1), and (iv) polarization studies. The latter refers to the angular dependence of the XANES or NEXAFS spectra and originates Fig. 4.11 Fitting of pre-edge peaks of Fe-K-edge micro-XANES spectra recorded in different spots from a vitroceramic sample with inhomogeneous distribution of Fe [55]. The blue regions (A) in the X-ray fluorescence image that maps the Fe K α emission intensity correspond to low Fe concentration and the red (B) to high Fe concentration. Fe in A and B is tetrahedrally and octahedrally coordinated, respectively from the linear polarization of the SR beam and the directionality of the covalent bonds. A characteristic case is that of carbon-related materials (more examples can be found in Sect. 6.5), the simplest example being that of highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG). The hexagonal rings formed by the C atoms lie parallel to the sample surface and normal to the hexagonal axis. sp 2 hybridization of the C atomic orbitals results in the formation of π* antibonding molecular orbitals (the direction of maximum electron charge density is along a vector normal to the carbon ring) and σ* orbitals that can be represented as planes of maximum electron charge density normal to the c-axis. The C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra of HOPG recorded in the TEY mode for various angles of incidence of the SR beam, θ, are shown in Fig. 4.14. The area under the characteristic π* resonance that appears at 285 eV depends linearly on cos 2 θ, as shown in the inset.

Key Research Findings
In the following, representative, recently published applications of the XAFS spectroscopy in various types of nanomaterials will be discussed.

Metallic and Intermetallic Nanomaterials
Metal or intermetallic nanoclusters, supported, embedded, or self-standing, comprise an important class of materials since they have the potential for several applications including catalysis and magnetic recording media as well as due to their superior tribological and optical properties.

Metal Nanocatalysts
Since the late 1970s, it was established that the catalytic activity increases significantly with increasing the surface area of the catalyst, thus driving their preparation in the form of tiny particles. A review on XAFS characterization of metallic and nonmetallic catalysts till late 1980s can be found in ▶ Chap. 8 of Ref. [11]. A more recent review can be found in Ref. [63]. The catalytic activity of nanocatalysts (e.g., Pt, Rh, Ni) can be improved further when they are deposited on supports (e.g., alumina, silica, TiO 2 ) with high surface area. In this case, the metal-oxide interface plays an important role in charge transfer. In homogeneous catalysis, where catalysts, reactants, and products are dissolved in the same phase, the catalyst is a coordination complex or an organometallic compound. Homogeneous catalysts comprised by a metal-ion core surrounded by ancillary ligands allow tuning of their structure toward optimization of their reactivity and selectivity. Heterogeneous catalysts lack such tunability, but they can be recyclable [64]. XAFS finds applications in the study of metallic nanocatalysts for the determination of the size of the nanocrystals (see Fig. 4.7), which is an important parameter affecting their activity.
In addition to that, XAFS provides information on the oxidation state of the nanocatalyst which is related to chemical effects and charge transfer. The latter can be assessed from the position of the absorption edge and the position and intensity of the white line as well as from the EXAFS spectrum that allows for the detection of different kinds of neighboring atoms. Finally, time-resolved XAFS (Quick-XAFS) is Polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cells offer solutions in energy production with applications from electric vehicles to power plants. However, aging of the catalyst is an important issue. Witkowska et al. studied the effect of aging of Pt nanocatalysts supported on Vulcan (E-TEK) with XAFS measurements at the Pt-L 3edge [65]. Aging for working times 0 to 150 h resulted in the variation of the size distribution of the Pt nanoparticles with the average size, as determined with XRD and TEM, increasing although remaining smaller than 3 nm. The Pt-L 3 -EXAFS spectra were fitted using the model of metallic Pt and the GNXAS ab initio code where the absorption cross section was expanded in terms of multiple scattering contributions up to the fifth neighbor [66]. Fourier transform of EXAFS and XANES spectra of the catalysts, as a function of the working time, is shown in Fig. 4.15. The peak intensity of the Fourier transform, and consequently the coordination numbers, increased, signifying an increase of the particle size. Furthermore, phase changes, for example, formation of PtO, did not take place due to the aging-induced degradation of the catalyst. The intensity of the white line (attributed to 2p ! d transitions) in the Pt-L 3 -XANES spectra (Fig. 4.15) decreased with aging. Although changes in the white-line intensity could be attributed to the variation of the particle size that affects the surface-to-volume atom ratio, the observed increase was much higher and was attributed to the occupancy of the 5d electronic states of the Pt atoms with aging. The usual method for the preparation of supported catalysts is impregnation. A solution of a metal precursor is added to the catalyst support followed by a drying or calcination process that promotes the formation of the metal particles on the supporting material. A reduction process (heating in a H 2 atmosphere) follows afterward. The formation of Pt nanoparticles on SiO 2 by impregnation in an aqueous solution of Pt(NH 3 ) 4 (NO 3 ) 2 was investigated using in situ time-resolved (Quick)-XAFS by Shishido et al. [67]. The Pt-L 3 -edge XAFS measurements were performed in H 2 or He flow. The in situ time-resolved Fourier transforms of the XAFS spectra and the corresponding XANES spectra, recorded in He flow with increasing temperature, are shown in Fig. 4.16. The XANES spectra revealed variations in the white line. More specifically, the intensity increased slightly when the temperature was increased from 460 to 500 K and then at 700 K decreased to the value that corresponds to metallic Pt. This variation in the intensity of the white line, which is consistent with the change in the oxidation state of Pt from +2 in the Pt(NH 3 ) 4 (NO 3 ) 2 precursor to 0 in the metallic Pt, is also verified by the shift in the absorption edge and the EXAFS spectra. At temperatures above 542 K, the Pt-Pt contribution of metallic Pt is detected in the Fourier transform (2.5-3 Å). On the other hand, the peak due to Pt-N and/or Pt-O bonding in Pt(NH 3 ) 4 (NO 3 ) 2 (~1.8 Å) loses intensity indicating the formation of metallic Pt at the expense of the precursor as a function of temperature. The gradual formation of Pt nanoparticles and the invariability of their size were verified by the linear combination fit of the XANES spectra using the spectra of Pt and the precursor. In situ time-resolved XAFS was applied in order to study the formation of Rh nanoparticles from the reaction of RhCl 3 ÁH 2 O and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) in ethylene glycol solution at elevated temperatures [68]. Direct comparison of the Rh-K-edge XANES spectra of the reaction mixture with the spectra of RhCl 3 ÁH 2 O and Rh metal revealed the progressive formation of metallic Rh at the expense of RhCl 3 ÁH 2 O within 1 h at the temperature of 408 K. Simulation of the XANES spectra of the mixture as a linear combination of the spectra of RhCl 3 ÁH 2 O and Rh foil was applied for the quantification of the Rh 3+ consumption rate. The analysis of the EXAFS spectra disclosed similar results. The Rh-Rh distance was found slightly shorter compared to the corresponding distance in bulk Rh. In addition to that, the average approximate particle size was determined from the coordination numbers. Comparison of the time evolution of the intensity of specific peaks in the Fourier transform provided information on the kinetics of Rh nanoparticle formation. Similar time-resolved XAFS studies on the formation kinetics of Cu, Rh, and Pd nanoparticles have been also reported [69,70].
Except from time-resolved studies applied for the investigation of the synthesis or aging processes, XAFS is also applied for the study of the structure of nanocatalysts. γ-Alumina-supported Pt nanoclusters with average particle size 0.8 nm were studied by means of Pt-L 3 -edge XAFS [71]. When the particles are so small, the cluster contains less than 300 atoms resulting in a drastic increase of the ratio of corners and edges relative to terrace atoms and thus affecting strongly the catalytic properties. The studied catalysts were prepared by impregnation of the Pt 2+ precursor on γ-Al 2 O 3 and reduction by heating for 10 min at 200 C under H 2 flow. Direct comparison of the catalyst XANES spectra with the spectra from reference Pt foil and PtO 2 samples revealed the metallic state of Pt. This result was also verified by the EXAFS spectra where a shell with coordination number 6.1 at a distance of 2.67 Å was identified. This distance is smaller compared to the corresponding distance in the bulk material (2.76 Å) due to the unsaturated environment of the metal atoms. This effect became less significant as the size of the cluster increased. In addition to the metallic state of Pt, a weak contribution of Pt-O was also detected. γ-Al 2 O 3 -supported Ag nanoparticles are effective catalysts for oxidant-free catalytic dehydrogenation of alcohols to carbonyl compounds. The efficiency of the H 2 reduction process was studied through Ag-K-XAFS [72]. The XANES spectra revealed that Ag was successfully reduced to metallic Ag, for Ag loadings 1-10 %, after heat treatment with H 2 . The formation of small metallic Ag nanoparticles was also verified by EXAFS. More specifically the number of Ag neighbors increased at the expense of O neighbors, while the smaller Ag-Ag distances, compared to the corresponding values in the bulk counterpart, identified the formation of nanoparticles. The determined Ag-Ag coordination numbers were used for the estimation of the nanoparticle size as a function of the Ag loading of the heterogeneous catalyst. Zeolites comprise a family of porous aluminosilicate minerals that can be used as catalysts. The catalytic activity of a Ag-loaded zeolite (ZSM-5) for the oxidation of CH 4 was studied by Kuroda et al. [73]. The changes in the Ag bonding environment with the evacuation temperature of the Ag-loaded zeolite were investigated using Ag-K-XAFS. It was found that above a certain temperature, Ag metal clusters were formed. The coexistence of Ag+ ions and small Ag metal clusters leads to prominent catalytic behavior in the partial oxidation of CH 4 , for the Ag-loaded zeolite evacuated at temperatures higher than of 573 K. Miller et al. [74] studied Au nanoparticles on different oxide supports (alumina, ceria, zirconia, and others) by means of Au-L 3 -edge XAFS measurements. Au exhibits catalytic activity for hydrogen-deuterium exchange, olefin hydrogenation, NO x reduction with H 2 , paraffin skeletal isomerization, and partial oxidation. Au nanoparticles are highly active for CO oxidation, with the activity increasing as the size of the Au particles decreases, especially when the particle size is less than 50 Å. The EXAFS characterization revealed that irrespective of the support oxide, both the coordination number in the first nearest neighboring shell and the interatomic distance decreased, due to the decrease in the nanoparticle size. The reactivity of Au nanoparticles with O 2 was also studied by the use of XAFS. Upon reaction with atmospheric air, the intensity of the white line in the XANES spectra increased revealing that about 10 % of the Au atoms were oxidized. Oxidation was further promoted at increased temperature. The degree of oxidation was also assessed from the Au-O peak that appeared in the Fourier transform of the EXAFS spectra at approximately 0.9 Å below the Au-Au peak. Kroner et al. [75] considered doping of Rh nanoparticles with ceria and/or zirconia, which is expected to increase the catalytic performance and improve the catalyst lifetime. The Rh nanoparticles were supported on γ-alumina, and the structure of the catalyst was studied with Rh-K-edge XAFS. Regarding potential applications, Rh is the main component in the three-way automotive exhaust catalyst due to its superior selectivity for NO x removal. In order to determine the oxidation state of the catalyst, its XANES spectra were compared with the spectra of Rh foil and Rh 2 O 3 . Both the position of the absorption edge and the intensity of the spectrum at a specific energy were taken into account. It was found that the Rh/Al 2 O 3 catalyst (prepared by impregnation with RhCl 3 ÁH 2 O, drying in air and reduction) contained mostly oxidized Rh particles. Furthermore, the method used for the ceriation of the Rh catalyst, i.e., Rh catalyst deposition on CeO 2 /γ-Al 2 O 3 or decomposition of metal-organic Ce(acac) 3 on Rh/γ-Al 2 O 3 , affected the degree of Rh oxidation, with the latter providing less oxidized Rh. Similar trends were observed in the zirconia-promoted Rh catalysts that were even less oxidized. Quantification of the amount of Rh that was oxidized was achieved by fitting the Rh-K-edge EXAFS spectra where the Rh-Rh and Rh-O distances yielded well-separated peaks in the Fourier transform (at 2.68 and 2.02 Å, respectively). The results supported that ceria and zirconia can protect the Rh particles from extensive oxidation. The size of the Rh particles, as it was deduced from the coordination numbers obtained from the EXAFS analysis, was discussed as a function of the synthesis method.
A method alternative to impregnation for the preparation of supported nanocatalysts is based on colloidal deposition. For the deposition of Pt on TiO 2 , the following procedure was followed: a Pt precursor was reduced to Pt nanoparticles in the presence of protecting polymers, then the nanoparticles were deposited on TiO 2 , and finally the polymers were decomposed and the Pt nanoparticles were reduced. Einaga et al. [76] prepared Pt/TiO 2 nanoparticles using DNA as a protecting polymer which stabilized the Pt colloid. The deposition of the colloid on TiO 2 was followed by annealing in O 2 atmosphere. Pt-L 3 -edge XAFS spectra were recorded for the study of both the Pt colloidal and the Pt/TiO 2 particles. As expected, the intensity of the peak in the Fourier transforms of the Pt colloids and the Pt/TiO 2 nanoparticles were characterized by very low intensity. Furthermore, only Pt-O (and not Pt-Pt) contributions were detected verifying the formation of small-sized Pt oxide colloid particles. Further oxidation occurred after the deposition process. The EXAFS results were verified by the XANES spectra, where the intensity of the white line was the characteristic of the formation of Pt oxide in the colloid.
Dendrimer-encapsulated Au nanoparticles, with size ranging from 1 to 2 nm, were investigated using EXAFS in order to evaluate an analysis model that would take into account the asymmetry in the bond-length distribution. Encapsulation within a dendrimer template results in negligible interactions with the support. On the other hand, controlled disorder of the Au nanoparticle was achieved by different concentrations of thiols which are small molecules that penetrate easily the dendrimer and are strongly adsorbed on the particle surface [77]. The Au-L 3 -edge EXAFS spectra of the nanoparticles were simulated taking into account the average signal of each Au atom, which was calculated using the atom sites determined by molecular dynamics. The accuracy of molecular dynamic simulations of such disordered systems was tested by its ability to reproduce accurately the experimental (EXAFS) spectra. The theoretically calculated pair distribution function for the Au-Au atom pair was compared with the experimentally determined Gaussian function used for the fitting of the Au nearest neighboring shell in the EXAFS spectra. As the coverage of the Au particle increased, the disorder increased and the pair distribution function deviated more from the symmetric distribution described by EXAFS. A similar approach was presented by Roscioni et al., where the EXAFS spectra of 2-6 nm nanoparticles were simulated using structural snapshots of the cluster obtained with molecular dynamic calculations. Averaging took place for different structural configurations and for all the photoabsorbing atoms in the cluster [78]. A similar approach was applied for modeling the EXAFS spectra of supported Pt nanoparticles [79]. A review on the methods used to model the EXAFS spectra of nanoparticles with various shapes, where issues like homogeneity, the width of the size and compositional distribution functions, were taken into account, can be found in Ref. [48]. In the same paper, multiple scattering contributions are also discussed.
Mixed noble metal nanoparticles have a higher conversion rate and thus are expected to exhibit superior catalytic properties compared to the single component counterparts resulting in lower required loadings. Therefore, optimal performance in direct methanol fuel cells has been achieved using a bimetallic catalyst. Christensen et al. [80] applied Ru-K-edge XAFS spectroscopy for the study of bimetallic Ru-Pt nanoparticles with average size of 1.2 AE 0.3 nm deposited on spherical alumina nanoparticles. The Ru-Ru distance was found smaller by 0.08 Å compared to the corresponding distance in the Ru foil. A Ru-Pt shell was also used to fit the EXAFS spectra. The results indicated that the nanoparticles were bimetallic and excluded formation of separate Pt and Ru particles. The formation of bimetallic particles was also supported by the redshift in the absorption edge of the Ru-K-edge XANES spectra of the studied particles compared to a pure Ru catalyst deposited on SiO 2 .
Except from the application of noble metals in catalysis, other metals are attractive for catalytic reactions as well. For example, Ni can be used in the CO 2 reforming of CH 4 , a reaction that finds applications in fuel cell technology as well as in the conversion of the greenhouse gases to a mixture containing H and CO. It also shows catalytic activity in reactions like hydrogenation of aromatic compounds and steam reforming reactions. Compared to noble metals, Ni has the advantage of higher abundance in nature. Higher catalytic activity is expected when the particle size is reduced to the nanoscale because the concentration of atoms with deficient coordination increases with decreasing volume-to-surface ratio. Wang et al. [81] studied, by means of Ni-and Co-K-edge XAFS spectroscopy, Ni, Co, and Ni x Co y nanoparticles prepared by coprecipitation or impregnation on MgAlO x supports. The spectra were recorded both from the reduced catalysts (heated at 750 C in H 2 / He flow for 4 h) and in situ during the reduction process. Representative XANES spectra of reduced catalysts recorded at the Ni-K-and Co-K-edge are shown in Fig. 4.17. Direct comparison of the spectra from the nanoparticles with those of the reference oxides and metal foils revealed that the catalysts were not fully reduced. To quantify the degree of oxidation, the XANES spectra were fitted as linear combinations of the spectra of the reference samples using proper weighting factors. The results were discussed as a function of the catalyst preparation process (impregnation and coprecipitation). Furthermore, the extent of reduction of the Ni and Co particles was also determined as a function of the duration of the reduction process by in situ XAFS measurements. The EXAFS spectra were also analyzed taking into account the degree of reduction as estimated by the XANES analysis. The size of the Ni and Co particles was inferred using the coordination numbers determined by EXAFS, as in the case of Pt catalysts [82]. The authors also discussed the effect of the interaction between Ni and Co as well as with the support structures on the catalyst reduction rate and stability in addition to the particle size distribution and dispersion uniformity. Kitagawa et al. [83] applied Ni-K-edge XAFS for the study of a Ni nanocluster catalyst on alumina. Small particle size and good homogeneity were achieved using colloidal methods with Ni loading approximately equal to 3 %. Direct comparison of the XANES spectra of the catalysts with that of NiO and Ni metal foil revealed that in all the samples the dominant species was Ni 0 . Linear combination fit determined that more than 80 % of Ni was reduced to Ni 0 excluding thus the formation of NiAl 2 O 4 which is a common phase formed during the preparation of the catalyst by impregnation methods. Regarding the EXAFS analysis, fitting was performed for the first nearest neighboring shell using the model of Ni metal. The coordination numbers were found to range from 6.7 to 10.3 (12 is the coordination number in the Ni foil) depending on the synthesis conditions.

Magnetic Metal Nanomaterials
XAFS spectroscopy is extensively applied for the study of magnetic materials, both for the investigation of their nanostructure and for the determination of spin and orbital magnetic moments using X-ray magnetic circular dichroism (XMCD). For the acquisition of the XMCD signal, left-and right-handed circularly polarized SR light is utilized and the corresponding spectra, recorded in the presence of a magnetic field, are subtracted. The theoretical background of the XMCD and the so-called sum rules that can be used to extract information on the magnetic moments from the spectra can be found in Refs. [84][85][86]. It should be reminded that the atom-selectivity of XAFS spectroscopy allows the quantification of the contribution of each specific element in the average magnetic behavior.
Metallic nanoparticles exhibit a variety of magnetic phenomena, for example, super-paramagnetism, magnetoresistance, and magnetic anisotropy. Their properties depend strongly on several parameters such as their size, structure, and morphology, as well as on their chemical composition and interactions with substrates, matrices, and/or capping layers. Colloidal systems consisting of Co nanoparticles, with size of approximately 3 nm, embedded in surfactant matrices were studied by means of Co-K-edge XANES. The Co nanoparticles were prepared by Co 2+ reduction of cobalt bis(2-ethylhexyl) sulfosuccinate Co(AOT) 2 and cobalt bis(2-ethylhexyl) phosphate Co(DEHP) 2 reverse micelle solutions [87]. In addition to XAFS, the authors used complementary characterization techniques including electron microscopy, to correlate the magnetic with the structural properties of the nanoparticles. The electron microscopy results indicated that the Co nanoparticles were oxidized. Therefore, the authors fitted the Co-K-edge XANES spectra as a linear combination of the spectra of hcp-Co (foil), CoO, Co 3 O 4 , Co 2+ in the unreacted micellar solution, and fcc-Co. The fcc-Co, Co 2+ , and Co 3+ contributions were necessary and their relative content in the nanoparticles was discussed as a function of the synthesis conditions and the type of the used micelle.
Binary nanoalloys attracted a lot of interest because they allow tuning of the magnetic moments and magnetic anisotropy energy. CoPt clusters in the form of truncated octahedrons, with a diameter of approximately 3 nm, crystallized in the fcc structure, were studied through Co-K and Pt-L 3 -edge XAFS. Chemical ordering in the tetragonal L1 0 phase was achieved after proper annealing [88]. Prior to annealing, the intensity of the Fourier transform peak that corresponded to the first neighbor of Co decreased along with the diameter of the nanoparticles. Furthermore, contraction of the lattice was observed. After annealing, the Co-K-and Pt-L 3 -edge spectra were fitted using the model of the L1 0 ordered phase using only Co-Pt atom pairs in the first nearest neighboring shell. Again the intensity of the first peak in the Fourier transform decreased with the diameter of the nanoparticles in accordance with finite size effects. Furthermore, the Co-Co distance was found smaller than the Co-Pt which in turn was shorter than the Pt-Pt due to local atomic relaxations. As a result, strong distortion in the pure Co planes occurs resulting in a "mismatch" with the underlying Pt atomic plane in chemically ordered L1 0 -like clusters. This distortion could explain the low magnetic anisotropy energy measured on chemically ordered CoPt nanomagnet assemblies. The EXAFS analysis was discussed in combination with the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP).
The formation of CoPt alloys after thermal treatment of Co nanoparticles on Pt (111) and Pt(100) films was investigated using XAFS spectroscopy. The use of textured substrates provides a method for ordered deposition of the Co nanoparticles which is important for a number of applications, for example, for chemical and biological sensors, data storage, and synthesis of nanowires and nanotubes [89]. The Co-L 2,3 -edge XMCD signal of the Co nanoparticles, in the as-prepared state as well as after in situ annealing in a H 2 atmosphere, was measured at the temperature of approximately 12 K. The element-specific hysteresis loops were also presented, and the differences in the coercive field for the orbital to spin moment ratios were discussed as a function of the properties of the substrate, either MgO(100) or SrTiO 3 (100), where the textured Pt films were grown.
Fe-containing nanosized metallic systems are promising materials for magnetic recording, development of mini magnets, and biological applications. In binary metallic alloys, with low concentration of the magnetic element, scattering of conduction electrons due to magnetic impurities results in a characteristic temperature dependence of the electrical resistivity (Kondo effect). At higher concentrations of the magnetic element, coupling of the nuclear magnetic moments or the localized inner shell (d or f) electron spins through the conduction electrons occurs. At even higher concentrations, ferromagnetic-like coupling takes place resulting in superferromagnetic behavior. Nanogranular thin films of Fe 7 Au 93 , Fe 7 Ag 93 , and Fe 9 Cu 91 sputtered on Si, with granule size smaller than 10 nm, were studied by means of XMCD at the Au-L 2,3 -edge (at 5 K and room temperature) and with Fe-K-edge XANES (at 77 K) [90]. Simulation of the Fe-K-edge spectra revealed that Fe partially formed nanoparticles (with bcc structure) and partially was diluted in the fcc matrix of the other metals. The XMCD signal at the Au-L 2,3 -edges demonstrated a net magnetic moment of the Au atoms, indicating that the Au atoms get polarized by the Fe nanoparticles. The magnetic moment of Au was increased further by approximately 15 % after annealing at 200 C. Furthermore, measurements at low temperatures produced an XMCD signal larger by one order of magnitude. Schmitz-Antoniak [91] studied Fe x Pt 1Àx nanoparticles by means of XAFS and XMCD at the Fe-K-and Pt-L-edge. The results were compared with the bulk counterparts. Fe x Pt 1Àx alloys crystallize in the fcc(bcc) structure for x < 0.8 (>0.8). The "chemical disorder" that is related to the formation of a random alloy can be estimated by taking into account the percentage of the Fe or Pt neighboring atoms as a function of x. Analysis of the EXAFS spectra revealed that the environment of Fe (Pt) was Fe-(Pt-) rich indicating that the FePt alloys were not random. However, EXAFS could not distinguish between random segregation and formation of a core/shell structure. Chemically ordered nanoparticles can be grown after annealing. The XMCD signal was measured at 15 K with the magnetic field pointing normal and almost parallel to the sample surface. Annealing resulted in an increase of the orbital magnetic moments, whereas the spin magnetic moment remained almost unaffected. At the Pt sites the magnetic moments were small and did not change upon annealing. XMCD was also applied for the study of Ni x Fe 1Àx nanowires. At certain compositions the magnetism of Ni x Fe 1Àx is not equal to the sum of the local moments of Ni and Fe but rather depends on the interactions between the two. These interactions rely strongly on the structure of the alloy because Ni and Fe adopt the fcc and bcc symmetries, respectively [92]. The XMCD spectra were recorded with the photon wave parallel to the wire's long axis. As the Ni concentration, x, increased, the structure changed from bcc (x = 0.3) to bcc and fcc (x = 0.5) and fcc (x = 1.0). Although the Fe-L 2,3 -and Ni-L 2,3 -edge XANES spectra did not depend strongly on the Ni concentration, strong variations were observed in the XMCD spectra. As shown in Fig. 4.18, when the Ni concentration increased, the Ni-edge XMCD signal decreased, whereas that of Fe increased. Furthermore, less Fe oxidation was observed as the Ni concentration increased. Annealing resulted in enhancement (suppression) of the Fe (Ni) XAS white-line intensities that reflected the available 3d states. The results indicated charge transfer from Ni to Fe.
Decreasing of the metal nanoparticle size results in variation of their magnetic properties. Thus, although bulk Rh, that is, a 4d metal, is paramagnetic, Rh nanoparticles tend to be ferromagnetic. Furthermore, the magnetic moment is strongly affected by the number of the atoms that comprise the nanoparticle. Barthem et al. [93] studied Rh nanoparticles comprised of about 150 atoms by Rd-L 2 -edge XMCD. They applied strong magnetic fields (2-17 T) in order to investigate their magnetic properties close to the onset of stable magnetism. The fact that the spin moment was found about 20 times higher than in the bulk counterpart and the non-expected temperature dependence of the XMCD signal were attributed to the correlation between electrons. Au exhibits also changes in the magnetic behavior when synthesized in the form of nanoparticles. Thus, although Au is a diamagnetic metal, when prepared in the form of nanoparticles with diameter of few nm, it becomes strongly paramagnetic, as it was verified by Au-L 2,3 -edge XMCD [94].
Magnetic proximity effects are phenomena that take place in heterostructures where the magnetic properties of the one layer control the properties of the other. Suturin et al. [95] studied ferromagnetic Co nanostructured films grown on antiferromagnetic MnF 2 with (111) surface orientation that has uncompensated spin structure with magnetic moments ideally out of plane by 35 . XAS spectra were recorded at the Co-L-and Mn-L-edges. XMCD spectra were also recoded with the magnetic field applied in the two opposite directions. The effectiveness of a 3 nm thick CaF 2 protective layer was proved from the XAS spectra of Co where no traces of oxidation were detected. The spectrum of the MnF 2 was as expected revealing that the Co/MnF 2 system was chemically stable and intermixing between the two layers did not take place. The XMCD signals of Co and Mn were opposite indicating the antiparallel coupling between the Co film and the Mn ion spins at the antiferromagnetic interface. Spectra recorded at normal incidence did not reveal an XMCD signal indicating that the magnetic moments were parallel to the surface, taking into is the sample magnetization. Element selective hysteresis loops were obtained from the XMCD signals of Mn and Co at 14 and 300 K. The Mn loops were antisymmetric to those of Co, but they had the same shape and width indicating that the majority of the Mn ions were controlled by the Co magnetization. Finally, the effect of the measurement temperature on the hysteresis loops was also discussed.
Gridneva et al. [96] studied Au/Co/Au dots organized on a Si 0.5 Ge 0.5 thin film capped with Si. These substrates have a characteristic faceted surface suitable for the evaporation of ordered structures. Taking into account that only the magnetization projected to the beam direction is probed, the sample was properly rotated in order to measure the magnetization normal and parallel to the surface. The external magnetic field was applied either parallel or perpendicular to the surface in two opposite directions. The remanence could be measured after the application of pulses of the magnetic field before the acquisition of the XAS spectrum. The authors discussed the values of the spin moments for out-of-plane and in-plane magnetization at 100 and 300 K for Au-capped Co and Au/Co films with various thicknesses of the Au and Co layers. Stable remanence of the Co/Au and Au/Co/Au magnetic nanodots grown on the nanostructured substrate was verified. The in-plane magnetic order was stable even at room temperature contrary to the out-of-plane magnetization that was stable only at low temperatures. The behavior of these nanodots is contrary to that of thin multilayers, most probably due to the interaction between the dots. EXAFS measurements at the Co-K-edge were also presented to account for relaxation phenomena.

Metal Nanoparticles for Optical Applications
Metal nanoparticles embedded in transparent matrices, e.g., silica glass, have attractive linear and nonlinear optical properties based mainly on surface plasmon resonance. The formation of Ag nanoparticles in aqueous ethanol solution of PVP by photoreduction of AgClO 4 using benzoin as photoactivator was studied means of in situ time-resolved Ag-K-edge EXAFS [97]. Prior to photoreduction, only the contribution of Ag-O could be detected in the spectra of the ionic solution of AgClO 4 . The formation of Ag-Ag bonds could be detected after photoreduction, with their contribution increasing with the exposure time. In the absence of benzoin, reduction of Ag from the AgClO 4 precursor was not complete. To investigate the kinetics of the Ag nanoparticle formation, time-resolved (dispersive) EXAFS spectra were recorded. It was found that after an induction period, the Ag-O bonds started to exponentially dissociate (i.e., Ag + was reduced to Ag 0 ) and Ag-Ag bonds (i.e., Ag nanoparticles) were formed. Values of the absorption coefficient at selected energies were used to quantify the rate of Ag-Ag formation, and coordination numbers obtained from the EXAFS analysis were used as a measure of the particle size. The latter was found to increase with time. The time scale for the observation of these changes was strongly affected by the presence of benzoin. The formation of Au nanoparticles by irradiation of the ionic liquid [BMIM] [AuCl 4 ] with synchrotron radiation was studied by means of in situ XAFS at the Au-L 3 -edge [98]. The XANES spectrum of the liquid prior to irradiation was measured by Quick-XAFS and had a characteristic white line. As the irradiation time increased, the intensity of the white line decreased, and after about 10 h of irradiation, the XANES spectrum became similar to the spectrum of Au foil signifying the formation of Au nanoparticles. In the corresponding EXAFS spectra, two peaks were detected corresponding to Cl and Au neighboring atoms with the number of Au neighbors increasing with irradiation time at the expense of Cl atoms.
Intermixing of Au and Ag for the formation of bimetallic Au-Ag nanoparticles was verified by EXAFS measurements at the Au-L 3 -edge since the backscattering amplitude of the Au is considerably different from this of Ag. Haug et al. [99] studied Ag-Au nanoparticles fabricated by ion implantation in glass by means of Ag-K-and Au-L 3 -edge XAFS measurements. They found that above a certain implantation dose, bimetallic Au-Ag nanoparticles were formed. Chen et al. [100] applied XAFS to compare Ag-Au alloys and Ag-Au core/shell structures (Ag core Au shell ) with the same Ag-Au atomic ratio. In the core/shell structure, more Au atoms were found to be bonded with Au.
The peculiar optical properties of metal nanoparticles lead to their use for decoration purposes in cultural heritage artifacts. Ag and Cu nanoparticles dispersed in a glassy matrix were used for coloring Medieval and Renaissance pottery. Padovani et al. [101] applied XAFS for the study of the metallic nanoparticles in lustered glazes of shards belonging to tenth-and thirteenth-century pottery. The luster used for the decorationwhich is actually a composite material consisting of glass and metal nanoparticleshad characteristic brilliant, metallic reflections, with mainly red and gold color. The extent of oxidation of the Ag and Cu nanoparticles was studied with EXAFS and XANES. In the latter case, linear combination fit with spectra of reference compounds (Cu 2 O, CuO, Cu, Ag, Ag 2 O) was performed for the determination of the percentage of the metallic phase in the nanoparticles. This information was important for the EXAFS analysis, because smaller coordination numbers, compared to the bulk values in the fcc structure, may be attributed to small size of the metal aggregates and/or their partial oxidation. In red luster partially oxidized Ag and Cu nanoparticles were detected. In gold luster Ag was partially oxidized, whereas Cu was present only in the oxidized form (with oxidation state +1 and +2) participating in different phases with S, Cl, and/or O. Similar studies on luster decoration of the thirteenth-century pottery were applied for the determination of the percentage of oxidized Cu aggregates which were related to color variations [102]. In order to detect changes in the microscale, micro-EXAFS spectra were recorded from sample spots with different colors as well as from other spots in the same decoration. The Cu-K-edge micro-EXAFS spectra were modeled as a weighted average of the spectra of Cu 2 O and metallic Cu. Red and green color was related to a higher content of Cu and Ag nanoparticles, respectively. However, in the green areas, higher content of Cu + compared to metallic Cu was also identified.

Semiconductor Nanostructures
Semiconducting nanostructures, for example, quantum dots (QD), nanoparticles (NP), quantum wells (QW), nanowires, nanorods, and nanoribbons, attracted a lot of interest for microelectronic, spintronic, and photonic applications. QDs are nanoparticles with dimensions of a few nanometers which are smaller than the exciton Bohr radius. This results in strong quantum confinement of the electronic states which affects the value and type (direct/indirect) of the energy gap. XAFS is extensively applied for the study of strain, size, and alloying effects in the nanostructure and the electronic structure of the nanoparticles, the extent of intermixing the QDs with the substrate or capping layers, their interaction with agents used in their synthesis, for monitoring the synthesis processes by time-resolved measurements, and for the study of the magnetic properties in transition element diluted semiconductors. Examples on the application of XAFS for the study of semiconductor nanomaterials can be found in Ref. [9].
A large number of applications of nanosemiconductors rely on their optical emission properties which in turn depend on their electronic structure. As discussed in Sect. 3, the XANES spectrum is analogous to the partial density of empty states. Thus, in the case of semiconductors, XANES is a tool for the investigation of the density of states in the conduction band with orbital character determined by the selection rules [Eq. (4.8)]. A modification of XANES spectroscopy that is often employed in semiconductors is X-ray excited optical luminescence (XEOL) spectroscopy, which is the X-ray analogue of photoluminescence. It studies the energy spectrum of the visible light emitted by the recombination of thermal electrons and holes (promoted to bottom of the conduction and top of the valence band, respectively) following the excitation with X-rays [9]. The luminescence yield in a specific energy range can be used for the acquisition of the XAFS spectra and for the discrimination of the various phases or sites in the sample that contribute to light emission.
To elucidate the origin of photoluminescence of Ge nanocrystals, Karatutlu et al. [103] used EXAFS, optically detected X-ray absorption spectroscopy (ODXAS), and XEOL spectroscopies. Depending on the synthesis routes of the nanoparticles, similarities or strong differences were found between the EXAFS and ODXAS, with the latter probing only sites in the sample that contribute to light emission. The differences between EXAFS and ODXAS were attributed to the presence of the GeO 2 phase. Ge and GaN quantum dots formed due to elastic strain on Si and AlN, respectively, were studied the use of XAFS [104]. The stacking sequence of the Ge/Si nanostructures with different number of Ge layers and different thickness of the Si barrier layer was studied at the Ge-K-edge. The total number of Si and Ge atoms in the first nearest neighboring shell was found equal to 4. The number of Ge atoms in the first shell was modified by the thickness of the Si barrier due to better nucleation of the Ge nanocrystals. The Ge-Ge distances were slightly smaller compared to those in bulk Ge. In the GaN/AlN heterostructures, the coordination number in the second nearest neighboring shell (consisting of Ga-Ga and Ga-Al bonds) was found to be affected by the thickness of the GaN layer and the formation of QD structures. EXAFS was also used to detect mixing between the nanoparticles and the matrix. For example, Cd-Zn intermixing between the CdSe QDs and ZnSe matrix was identified by Cd-K-edge EXAFS [105].
PdS QDs have potential applications in solar cells. The band gap of PbS is very sensitive to finite size effects (it takes values in the range 0.4-2.8 eV depending on the QD size) since the exciton Bohr radius is approximately 20 nm, a value considerably larger than in other nanoparticles. Demchenko et al. [106] studied colloidal PbS nanoparticles (~50 nm) and QDs (~5 nm) with S-K-edge XANES. They found that the absorption edge of the QDs was blueshifted by about 1.67 eV compared to the bulk counterpart. This observation was attributed to the increase of the band gap and more specifically to the shift of the conduction band minimum. Simulations of the XANES spectra of bulk and QD PbS, taking into account the cluster size in the latter case, were performed in order to explain the variations observed in the experimental spectra. The conduction band minimum of the semiconductor QDs is also affected by the doping. Cd-M 3 -edge XANES spectra of Cu-doped CdSe QDs, with a diameter of 5 nm, were used to study the effect of Cu concentration on the energy of the conduction band minimum [107]. The onset of the absorption edge can be assigned to the lowest unoccupied states after taking into account the selection rules that determine the type of the final state [108]. The differences in the energy gap of the QDs and their bulk counterparts were attributed to various effects including confinement, electron-hole binding, doping, and hybridization of the wave functions of Cu and Cd. Hybridization appeared to be important for the explanation of the experimental data at the Cd-M 3 -edge. On the contrary the hybridization term was not important in the Se-L 3 -edge spectra. A theoretical model that accounts for the hybridization of the dopant and host atom states, which also takes into account the size-dependent bond-length variation, was presented in Ref. [109]. This model explains very well the experimental results on the conduction band minimum as determined from the Cd-M 3 -edge XANES spectra of Cu-doped CdSe QDs.
The use of ternary instead of binary semiconductors offers more flexibility for band gap engineering, since the gap can be controlled by either altering the size or the stoichiometry. On the other hand, the photoluminescence quantum yield of QDs is expected to increase when a thin layer with a higher band gap blankets the core, resulting in strong confinement. CdSe x S 1Àx QDs with size of 5 nm and 0 < x < 1 were studied through XAFS spectroscopy at the Cd-K-and Se-K-edge [110]. The EXAFS results indicated phase separation in the form of a core/shell structure that was held responsible for the enhancement of the photoluminescence quantum efficiency for increasing values of x. The results were substantiated by the fact that the Se-K-edge XANES spectra were not affected by the change of the Se content. Contrary to the formation of core/shell structures, in homogeneous, random alloys, variations were observed in both the Cd-K-and Se-K-edge spectra with the variation of x [111].
Another ternary alloy that was studied in the form of nanocrystals is Mg x Zn 1Àx O. Band gap engineering via control of the value of x results in materials with optoelectronic applications in the UV spectral region. However, in this case the end binary compounds, ZnO and MgO, crystallize in different structures, wurtzite and rocksalt, respectively. The bonding environment of Mg and Zn in Mg x Zn 1Àx O (0 < x < 1) nanocrystals was studied through XANES by Limpijumnong et al. [112]. The XANES spectra recorded at the Zn-K-and Mg-K-edges were simulated using the models of MgO, where Zn substitutes for Mg in sixfold coordinated sites, and of ZnO, where Mg substitutes for Zn in fourfold coordinated sites. Using this formulation, the authors determined the fraction of the fourfold or sixfold coordinated Zn and Mg atoms as a function of x.
The emission properties of ZnO-ZnS nanoribbons were studied with XANES at the Zn-K-and S-L 2,3 -edges employing the luminescence yield (emission in the visible spectrum) for the acquisition of the spectra [113]. Comparison of the S-Kedge XANES spectra recorded in the total electron yield and luminescence yield revealed similar signals in ZnS powder and nanowires, whereas luminescence yield was diminished in the spectrum of the ZnS-ZnO nanoribbons. This was an indication that S (and consequently ZnS) did not contribute in the optical decay channel. Similar results were obtained for the S-L 2,3 -edge. The Zn-K-edge spectra of the nanoribbons, recorded in the luminescence yield, were similar to the spectra of ZnO nanoneedles and exhibited strong differences with the spectrum of ZnS nanowires, verifying that ZnS does not contribute to the luminescence of the nanoribbons. SnO 2 is an n-type semiconductor that is widely used in flammable gas sensors. Rammutla et al. [114] studied doping of SnO 2 with Y 3+ and Zr 4+ which are expected to improve its sensing properties. The as-prepared samples had crystallite sizes of ~3 nm, whereas heating up to 1000 C resulted in an increase of the size to ~40 nm. EXAFS analysis at the K-edge of the dopant revealed that Y was incorporated in the SnO 2 lattice when the sample was annealed at temperatures higher than 900 C. On the contrary, Zr substituted for Sn at temperatures as low as 200 C.
Semiconductor nanowires are promising structures for various applications including memory, sensing, logic, light emission, and waveguiding. Segura-Ruiz et al. [115] studied In x Ga 1Àx N nanowires by nano-XANES, nano-XRD, and nano-X-ray fluorescence (XRF) with a spatial resolution of 55 nm. XRF and XRD revealed the existence of strong phase separation both from the edge to the center and from the bottom to the top of the nanowire. The Ga-K-edge XANES spectra recorded with the electric field vector of the SR beam parallel and perpendicular to the c-axis, exhibited angular dependence characteristic of the wurtzite structure excluding the formation of metallic phases at both the bottom and the top of an individual wire. Cross-shaped semiconducting nanowires gained considerable attention for interconnection applications in nanodevices. Martínez-Criado et al. used X-ray nano-beam to study junctions created in Ga 2 O 3 /SnO 2 multiwire structures, focusing on the intersection [116]. The Ga-K-edge XANES spectra recorded in the junction and on the Ga 2 O 3 nanowire (i.e., out of the junction) were the same indicating that intermixing with SnO 2 does not take place at the junction. The spectra were interpreted as having contributions of both tetrahedrally and octahedrally coordinated Ga with oxygen atoms.
Incorporation of magnetic ions in semiconductor QDs has also attracted a lot of interest, since the magnetic properties due to orbital exchange can be further tuned by the size of the nanoparticle. Such diluted magnetic semiconductor QDs are attractive for spintronics, quantum computing, and magneto-optical applications. Ga 1Àx Mn x As is a ferromagnetic semiconductor with a Curie temperature of 191 K. Self-assembled Ga 0.92 Mn 0.08 As QDs with mean diameter of 16.5 nm, grown epitaxially on Si, were investigated using Mn-K-edge XANES spectroscopy [117]. The spectrum of the QDs resembled the spectrum of the single-crystalline film, revealing that Mn was divalent, substituted for Ga, and was tetrahedrally coordinated with As. As in the case of the Ga 1Àx Mn x As film, ferromagnetic order in the QDs was probably mediated by the presence of holes since Mn acts as an acceptor substituting for Ga. Similar results were obtained in the case of Ga 1Àx Mn x As (x 0.05) nanowires [118]. The sample with x = 0.03 exhibited the highest magnetic moment among the studied samples. The temperature dependence of the Mn-L 2,3 -edge XMCD signal was also discussed.
Mn-doped GaN nanowires were studied by means of Mn-K-edge XAFS and Mn-L 2,3 -XMCD [119]. It was found the Mn atoms substitute for Ga sites participating in the formation of the wurtzite network of host GaN. The XMCD spectra revealed that Mn had local magnetic moment and the electronic configuration of the doped Mn was mainly 3d 5 . In another study, Mn-doped GaN nanowires with ~10 at. % Mn concentration were studied by means of Mn-L 2,3 -edge XANES combined with scanning transmission X-ray microscopy (STXM) [120]. The latter allowed the generation of images using a beam with diameter of 30 nm that raster-scanned the sample. The XANES spectrum at a given element edge was reconstructed from a stack of images recorded in an energy range close to the absorption edge of the element of interest. The spectra obtained at preselected positions on an individual nanowire were studied. It was found that Mn substitutes for Ga uniformly along the wire. Linear combination fit of the spectra revealed that 70 % was Mn 2+ and 30 % Mn 3+ , both in tetrahedral coordination. Mn-L 2,3 -edge XMCD measurements demonstrated that the magnetic moment was at least one order of magnitude higher compared to Mn-doped bulk GaN crystals. This finding was attributed to the longrange order of the Mn dopants. Finally, the authors discussed the variations of the XMCD signal with the orientation of the nanowire.
The incorporation of Cr 3+ ions in the lattice of ZnSe QDs was studied by means of Cr-L 2,3 -edge XANES [121]. The energy and spectral shape of the L 2,3 edge revealed that Cr was trivalent. To achieve satisfactory simulation of the XANES spectra, a tetragonal distortion was assumed for the octahedron around Cr, where the Cr-Se bond was compressed along the z-axis. Such a distortion was explained by the removal of Zn atoms for charge balance reasons.
Fe-doped ZnO is another example of a diluted magnetic semiconductor. Zn 0.99 Fe 0.01 O nanorods synthesized by coprecipitation were studied by means of O-K-and Fe-L 2,3 -edge XANES [122]. The spectra of the nanorods recorded at the Fe-L 2,3 -edge are compared with the spectra of reference Fe oxides. The strong similarity of the nanorod spectrum with that of Fe 2 O 3 revealed that Fe was trivalent in Zn 0.99 Fe 0.01 O. Thus substitution of Zn by Fe atoms would result in excess of holes that could be responsible for the weak room temperature ferromagnetism. Increase of x up to 0.05 in Zn 1Àx Fe x O nanorods resulted in a variation of the Fe 3+ /Fe 2+ ratio although Fe still substituted for Zn [123]. ZnO nanowires doped with Co by means of ion implantation were studied by means of XRF and XANES spectroscopy with a 100 nm spatial resolution [124]. Such resolution allows for the study of a single nanowire. XRF imaging revealed the homogeneous distribution of Co throughout the wire. The Zn-K-edge spectra were recorded for two different sample orientations, i.e., with the electric field of the beam parallel and perpendicular to wire's axis, which is parallel to the c-axis of the crystal. In the former case 1s ! p z transitions were favored, whereas in the latter case 1s ! p x,y transitions dominated. The angular dependence of the spectra revealed that implantation and subsequent annealing did not induce structural disorder. Figure 4.19 shows the Co-K-and Zn-K-edge XANES spectra recorded at two spots on the nanowire.
For better comparison, the energy scale was shifted by an amount equal to the energy of the absorption edge of each atom. The strong similarities between the spectra revealed that Co substitutes for Zn. Furthermore, the position of the absorption edge (which is the same with that of the thin film alloy) indicates that Co is divalent. The Zn-K-edge EXAFS spectra recorded at different spots in the wire did not exhibit differences and did not show evidence of significant structural disorder.
Size reduction in semiconductor structures triggered peculiar phenomena like the observation of ferromagnetic behavior of nonmagnetic materials. This behavior has been attributed to symmetry breaking at the surfaces and the consequent modification of the electronic structure. ZnO nanoparticles with dimensions of 20 nm capped with different organic molecules (trioctylphosphine, dodecylamine, and dodecanethiol) were studied by means of XMCD [125]. The Zn-K-edge XMCD signal of ZnO nanoparticles capped with dodecanethiol, measured with magnetic fields of 2-10 T, exhibited differences compared to the other two capping molecules. The differences were attributed to the formation of a ZnS-like phase with the S atoms of dodecanethiol. To explain the dependence of the XMCD intensity on the applied magnetic field, the coexistence of two different magnetic contributions was assumed. The core of the nanoparticles contributed with a paramagnetic term, whereas a ferromagnetic-like contribution stemmed from the interface between the capping organic molecule and the ZnO nanoparticle. The ferromagnetic-like behavior was reinforced when neat interfaces were formed, as in the case of dodecanethiol capping layer.
ZnO nanorods can be grown with a hydrothermal method using Zn acetate as a precursor and surfactant which is necessary for the modulation of the crystal morphology and size of the nanoparticles [126]. A seed layer of Zn/sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) was used in order to grow well-oriented nanorods. Zn-L 2,3 -edge spectra of the Zn/SDS seed layer and the ZnO nanorod films were recorded for different growth reaction times (5 min-4 h). The spectra of Zn/SDS and ZnO were considerably different allowing monitoring of the evolution of the ZnO nanorods. Gradual variations of the spectra were observed up to reaction times of 30 min at which time ZnO was formed. The XANES spectra did not change for longer reaction times. Zn-K-edge time-resolved XAFS was applied for the investigation of the formation mechanism of ZnO nanoparticles via sol-gel synthesis using zinc acetate salt dissolved in alcohol media [127]. The EXAFS oscillations, i.e., the χ(k) spectra, were fitted as a linear combination of the corresponding spectra of nano-ZnO and the unreacted precursors in the solution, as a function of the aging time. The amount of ZnO formed (about 17 % of the Zn in the precursor was converted to ZnO) in the hydrolyzed solutions at 60 C reached a plateau after 45 min. Similar results were obtained in Ref. [128]. Another in situ time-resolved XAFS study of the synthesis process of ZnSe QDs capped with glutathione was performed at the Se-K-edge [129]. Only one peak, which corresponds to the Zn neighboring shell of Se in the zincblende structure of ZnSe, was visible in the Fourier transform of the spectra. The formation of ZnSe crystals started when the solution was heated just to 80 C, without any time elapse, indicating that the formation of ZnSe QDs from aqueous formation undergoes a fast nucleation process. As the reaction time elapsed, the coordination number in the first nearest neighboring shell progressively increased approaching the corresponding value in the ZnSe crystal.
A promising method for the synthesis of QDs is based on microorganisms due to the low-cost and environment-friendly character of the process. Fellowes et al. [130] studied the ex situ formation of CdSe QDs using bacterially generated Se 2À as an alternative precursor. CdSe nanoparticles, synthesized using abiotic and biogenic Se 2À and Cd(ClO 4 ) 2 -glutathione solution, were characterized by S-K-edge XANES in order to investigate the interaction between the glutathione capping agent and the QDs. The S-K-edge XANES spectra of the synthesized CdSe QDs were compared with the spectra of reference compounds. The CdSe QD spectrum exhibited strong similarities with the spectrum of CdS, indicating that S originating from glutathione was incorporated in the QD structure. Se-K-edge XANES was used to investigate the stability of abiotic and biogenic Se 2À under SR irradiation. Compared to abiotic Se 2À solution, which exhibited oxidation to Se 6+ upon SR irradiation for 15 min, the biogenic Se 2À was not susceptible to oxidation. The behavior of the latter was explained by the presence of proteins in the biogenic Se 2À solution that acted as stabilizing agents. Time-resolved XANES was applied to the Se-K-edge in order to investigate the differences between the uses of abiotic and biogenic Se 2À precursors in the formation of ZnSe QDs. Addition of ZnCl 2 -β-mercaptoethanol (βME) in biogenic and abiotic Se 2À solution resulted in rapid formation of βME-ZnSe. The Se-K-edge XANES spectra for both the biogenic and abiotic Se 2À solutions differed significantly from the spectra of the βME-ZnSe. Intensity differences at characteristic energies in the time-resolved XANES spectra of Se 2À solutions and βME-ZnSe were used to monitor the rate of formation of the ZnSe QDs.
Semiconductor QDs are used for biological imaging as well. The stability of water soluble ZnO QDs with diameters 3 nm and 4 nm was investigated in vivo in oral epidermoid carcinoma cells by Zn-K-edge XANES [131]. The absorption of the QDs with a copolymer shell in the cells was verified by proton-induced X-ray emission (PIXE) imaging. It was found that the bonding configuration of Zn was stable and did not change upon absorption in the cell.

Metal Oxide Nanomaterials
Metal oxides find numerous applications in catalysis, as electrodes for Li-ion batteries, for magnetic and biomedical applications, etc. XAFS spectroscopies are extensively applied for the determination of the oxidation state of the metal, of the coexistence of various phases in the sample, and for the site preference, e.g., tetrahedral or octahedral coordination.

Metal Oxides Used for Electrodes
Sn-based nanomaterials are used as anode materials for rechargeable Li-ion batteries.
Monodisperse and size tunable Sn/SnO x nanoparticles (with Sn core diameter in the range 10-20 nm and oxide shell thickness of 3 nm) were studied by means of Sn-Kedge XAFS [132]. The Sn-K-edge XANES spectra of the nanoparticles were fitted as a linear combination of the spectra of reference compounds (Sn, SnO, SnO 2 ). It was reported that in the smaller nanoparticles, the concentration ratio [Sn/(Sn-oxide)] was smaller compared to the value corresponding to the larger ones. This finding explained the high charge storage capacities and the improved cycling stability of nanoparticles with size smaller than 10 nm. Another anode material is CoO. Co-K-edge EXAFS spectroscopy was applied for the study of CoO nanoparticles obtained by calcination (i.e., heating in N 2 atmosphere) of Co(OH) 2 at 200 and 900 C [133]. The variations in the coordination numbers in the first and second nearest neighboring shells for the two different calcination temperatures were interpreted as variations in the oxygen-to-cobalt ratio. MnO is another attractive anode material for rechargeable Li-ion batteries. Porous MnO microspheres were characterized by ex situ Mn-K-edge XAFS [134]. The XANES spectra of the pristine sample were identical to the spectra of MnO. After discharge to 0 V, the XANES spectrum changed and became similar to that of metallic Mn. After recharging, the pre-edge peak reappeared with a higher intensity (indicating larger distortion of the bonding environment of Mn), and the absorption edge returned to the position that corresponded to the pristine sample. However, the spectral features above the absorption edge were broader indicating that the crystalline quality was not fully restored. The linear dependence of the position of the absorption edge on the oxidation state was also applied [135] for the determination of the Mn oxidation state in MnO x samples. The oxidation state of Mn changed during charge-discharge cycles of composite MnO 2 -carbon nanotubes (MnO 2 /CNT) which are candidates for electrochemical capacitors in energy storage devices, with applications in electric vehicles, uninterruptible power supplies (UPS), etc. [136]. The spectra of the MnO 2 /CNT, in the as-prepared state, as well as after heat treatment, were recorded during charge-discharge cycles and were compared to the spectra of reference oxides (MnO, Mn 2 O 3 , MnO 2 ). Charging of the electrode resulted in a blueshift of the absorption edge, consistent with an increase of the oxidation state of Mn (between 3 + and 4+), while discharge had the opposite effect due to the reduction of the oxidation state of Mn (between 2+ and 3+). This observation indicated that the electrochemical reaction of the MnO 2 /CNT nanocomposite electrode during charge-discharge was due to Faradaic redox reaction between MnO 2 and Li + accompanied by changes in the oxidation state of Mn. Electrochemical measurements of Sn 1Àx Co x O 2Àx nanocrystals revealed that the substitution of Sn with Co significantly enhanced the negative electrode performance [137]. Co-K-and Sn-L 3 -XANES spectroscopy for various ratios of the Co and Sn precursors identified that the oxidation state of Co and Sn was +2 and +4, respectively.
Lithium manganese oxides (LMO) comprise another family of oxides used for Li-ion batteries. Although nanostructured materials have a number of advantages, for example, shorter diffusion length and faster pathway for Li-ion transport, they also present certain disadvantages such as particle agglomeration and reduced packing density. To overcome such problems, hybrid materials with metal nanoparticles of 20-50 nm size were homogeneously dispersed in a CNT network. The samples were prepared by heating MnO 2 -coated CNT composite with appropriate amounts and concentrations of an aqueous LiOH solution [138]. The position of the absorption edge and the EXAFS spectra were used for the determination of the oxidation state of Mn for different LiOH concentrations. Low LiOH concentration resulted in the spinel-type LiMn 2 O 4 where the oxidation state of Mn, which occupies a site with Jahn-Teller distortion, is 3.5+. At higher LiOH concentrations, the layered-type Li 2 MnO 3 phase was formed where Mn is tetravalent and free of Jahn-Teller distortion.
Another metal oxide that has been proposed for applications in electrodes is GeO 2 . The Coulombic efficiency (defined as the amount of charge that exits the battery during the discharge cycle to the amount of charge that enters the battery during the charge cycle) of this oxide can be improved by adding metallic components. Kim et al. [139] studied MGeO 3 (M = Cu, Fe, and Co) where the additional metal components (M) are expected to form nanosize particles. The XAFS spectra that were recorded at the Ge-K-and Cu-K-edge at various stages of the discharge-charge process of the CuGeO 3 /Li cell are shown in Fig. 4.20.
The Cu-K-and Ge-K-edge spectra of the CuGeO 3 electrode at the beginning of the process (point 1) revealed that the oxidation states of Cu and Ge were +2 and +4, respectively. As the lithiation process proceeded, Cu was reduced to its metallic state. Reduction of Ge occurred at a later stage. The XANES observations were supported by the EXAFS spectra. In the corresponding Fourier transforms, the evolution of the formation of Cu and Ge metals, at the expense of the corresponding oxides, was tracked from the intensity of the Cu-Cu (Ge-Ge) and Cu-O (Ge-O) peaks, respectively. Similar XAFS analysis revealed that during delithiation (points 6-10) Cu remained mainly in the metallic state, whereas Ge started to oxidize after point 8. It was proposed that the formation of the Cu metal nanoparticles promotes the oxidation of Ge, thus improving the Coulombic efficiency of the electrode.
Layered double hydroxides (LDH) are described with the general formula The formation mechanism of MoO 2 nanorods, which are also used as electrodes, was studied with in situ Mo-K-edge XANES spectroscopy. A linear combination fit of the spectra obtained during the synthesis reaction with the spectra of the MoO 2 Cl 2 precursor and the final product yielded the ratio of the two phases. After 90 min, about 90 % of the precursor was converted to MoO 2 [141].
Metal oxides can be combined with conducting polymers for the formation of composite electrodes. NiO-polypyrrole (PPy) nanocomposites were studied at the

Normalized X-ray Absorption (a.u.) Normalized X-ray Absorption (a.u.) Ni-K-edge at various stages of the discharge/recharge cycle [142]. The EXAFS spectrum of the as-prepared NiO-PPy composite is the same with the spectrum of NiO indicating that NiO was unaffected by the PPy coating. However, strong interaction between Ni and PPy occurred in the discharged electrode, where Ni was bonded with N (the Ni-N distance was found equal to 2.18 Å). Linear combination fitting of the EXAFS spectra revealed the variation of the percentage of PPy-Ni-O, metallic Ni, and NiO during the discharge/recharge process. The structure of the PPy-Ni-O complex was modeled with density functional theory calculations.
TiO 2 is another oxide with applications in Li-ion batteries. Zhou et al. [143] studied TiO 2 nanotube arrays prepared by anodic oxidation of Ti foil before and after intercalation of Li. The XANES spectra were recorded at the Ti-L 2,3 , O-K, and Li-K edges. In the Ti-L 2,3 -edge spectra, the splitting due to spin-orbit coupling, which determines the L 2 -L 3 -edge separation, is much smaller compared to heavier transition metals. For an ideal octahedral environment of Ti, the combination of spin-orbit coupling and modification of the states by the crystal field resulted in two double peaks in the L 3 (at approximately 458 and 460 eV) and the L 2 (at approximately 463 and 465 eV) edges. In the case of the anatase and rutile polytypes of TiO 2 , tetragonal distortion caused further splitting of the peak that appears at 460 eV with the relative intensity of the two components depending on the polytype. The spectra of the annealed TiO 2 nanotube arrays revealed that they adopted the anatase structure. For the as-prepared samples, splitting due to tetragonal distortion was not observed and the peaks were significantly broader indicating higher disorder. The effect of annealing on the crystalline quality of the sample was also deduced from the O-K-edge spectra. The Li-K-edge spectra of the Li-intercalated nanotubes indicated that Li was in the ionic state. The Ti-L 2,3 -edge spectra recorded after Li intercalation indicated that TiO 2 was distorted after the intercalation with rutile being the dominant phase, most probably due to charge redistribution. Finally, crystallization of 9 nm TiO 2 nanoparticles synthesized by the chemical vapor synthesis in the anatase structure was also verified by Ti-K-edge XANES [144].

Oxide Catalysts
Pure TiO 2 or doped with metallic ions finds applications in photocatalysis which has many applications, for example, in water splitting, organic pollutant scavenging, and antifouling. The size of the nanoparticles, their composition, and the presence of oxygen vacancies are important parameters for their photocatalytic function. TiO 2 is stabilized in three phases: rutile is stable for macroscopic crystals, while brookite and anatase can be stable in nanoparticles. The photocatalytic activity of TiO 2 was found to be dependent on the adopted phase and/or the formation of a mixture of two phases. C.-Yu Liao et al. [145] applied XAFS for the study of mesoporous TiO 2 hollow spheres which have potential applications in the photoanodes of dye-sensitized solar cells where they play an important role on the loading of the sunlight sensitive dyes. The XANES spectra recorded at the Ti-K-edge are characterized by a pre-edge peak, similar to the one in the Fe-K-edge spectra discussed previously. The pre-edge peak of the studied mesoporous TiO 2 had four contributions that were attributed to tetrahedrally coordinated (TiO 4 ), fivefold square pyramid [(Ti = O)O 4 ] and octahedrally coordinated Ti. The authors deconvoluted each contribution using proper fitting with Gaussian-Lorentzian peaks and determined the percentage of the square-pyramid Ti polyhedra which have high activity for photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants. The deconvolution of the pre-edge peak by peak fitting is shown in Fig. 4.21. Analysis of the EXAFS spectra revealed that mesoporous TiO 2 is characterized by smaller coordination numbers compared to nano-TiO 2 . The photo-conversion efficiency of the mesoporous material was much better compared to the nanosized one.
Kityakarn et al. [146] studied Ce-doped TiO 2 nanoparticles by means of XANES. Doping of TiO 2 with Ce improves its photocatalytic activity. The Ti-K-edge spectra of Ti 1Àx Ce x O 2 (x = 0-0.1) were fitted using linear combinations of the anatase, rutile, and brookite spectra. It was found that upon Ce doping, the anatase/rutile mixture was replaced by anatase/brookite. The Ce-L 3 -edge XANES spectra revealed that the dominant oxidation state of Ce was 4+ with a small contribution of Ce 3+ for low doping levels.
Enhancement of the photocatalytic efficiency of titanate nanotubes in dissolution of organic pollutants is improved with the addition of Cu dopants. R.-a. Doong et al. [147] studied Ti-K-and Cu-L 2,3 -edge XANES titanate nanotubes that were calcined to form TiO 2 -titanate nanotube nanocomposites doped with Cu 2+ . From the relative intensity of the components of the pre-edge peak in the Ti-K-edge spectra, it was deduced that the as-prepared titanate nanotubes adopted a layered structure, whereas calcination and Cu photo-deposition led to the formation of the anatase structure. Another promising strategy to reduce the electron-hole recombination is the formation of a heterostructure. Mourão et al. [148] reported on the synthesis of TiO 2 nanostructures and TiO 2 :SnO 2 heterostructures. The materials were synthesized from TiO 2 and SnCl 2 Á 2H 2 O precursors which were subjected to hydrothermal treatment using KOH solutions with various concentrations. The Ti-K-edge spectra of the TiO 2 and the TiO 2 /SnO 2 nanostructures with a small value of the Ti/Sn ratio, prepared at lower KOH concentrations, revealed that the samples adopted the anatase structure. On the contrary, in the spectra from the sample with a higher value of the Ti/Sn ratio, a characteristic contribution in the pre-edge peak (A2 in Fig. 4.21) was detected. This contribution, which was considerably higher, was attributed to five-coordinated Ti due to the elongated morphology of the nanostructures prepared under these conditions. The photocatalytic activity of TiO 2 is enhanced with deposition of noble metals on its surface. Ag-L 3 -edge XANES spectra of Ag-modified TiO 2 with average size of approximately 7 nm showed that Ag was in the Ag + ionic state [149].
ZnO has a direct and wide band gap and thus finds applications in UV shielding. However, it also exhibits photocatalytic activity that hinders its applications in UV shielding. For example, it causes skin damage, deterioration of paints and plastics, and color fading in plastics and fabrics. It has been proposed that the photocatalytic activity of ZnO can be reduced by doping with Co.
