The bonding configuration of Co dopants in ZnO nanoparticles (with particle size 10-50 nm) and doping levels 0.25-5 at.% was studied by means of XAFS [150]. The authors reported that the photocatalytic activity of the ZnO nanopowders, as determined via the decomposition of dye molecules under simulated sunlight, is indeed reduced with Co doping. The Co-K-edge XANES spectra of the Co-doped ZnO nanoparticles were compared with spectra of the reference compounds CoO, Co 2 O 3 , and Co-methylimidazole. In CoO, Co 2+ is octahedrally coordinated resulting in a low-intensity broad pre-edge peak, whereas in Co-methylimidazole the tetrahedral coordination of Co gives rise to a sharp pre-edge peak. Judging from the intensity of the pre-edge peak, Co was found tetrahedrally coordinated in the Co-doped ZnO. In addition to that, from the position of the absorption edge, it was deduced that its oxidation state was +2. The EXAFS analysis revealed that Co substitutes for Zn retaining the tetrahedral coordination of Zn in ZnO. The incorporation of Co in host lattice sites, instead of interstitial positions, is held responsible for the reduction in the photocatalytic activity, most probably due to the creation of deep levels in the gap that act as electron-hole traps.
MnO 2 catalysts have potential applications for electrochemical water splitting that is a key step in the use of H 2 in energy storage. MnO 2 exists in a number of polymorphs that adopt layered or tunneled structures where the octahedra around Mn share corners and/or edges. Bergmann et al. [151] studied Mn-K-edge XAFS of MnO 2 synthesized with two different methods, symproportionation deposition-precipitation (s) and incipient wetness impregnation (i). The XANES spectra revealed that the oxidation state of Mn was around 3.5+ and 3+ and became 3.5+ in both cases after deposition on the electrode. After the electrocatalytic process, the oxidation state of Mn in both cases increased to 4+. Analysis of the EXAFS spectra revealed that Mn was octahedrally coordinated. The nanoparticles synthesized by the s-method adopted a layered structure with edge-sharing octahedra, whereas in those synthesized by the i-method, significant contribution of corner sharing was detected.
ZrO 2 -CeO 2 substitutional solid solutions attracted interest due to their applications in three-way catalysts. ZrO 2 is added to inhibit the CeO 2 deactivation. On the other hand, the catalytic activity of the ceria-zirconia catalysts is improved with the interaction of noble metal phases. Acuña et al. [152] studied pure Zr 0.1 Ce 0.9 O 2 and Zr 0.1 Ce 0.9 O 2 /Pd nanotubes. The latter were studied also after reduction. Comparison of the Ce-L 3 -edge XANES spectra of the samples with spectra of reference compounds, which contained Ce 3+ and Ce 4+ , revealed that Ce was mainly in the tetravalent state in all the samples. A small amount of Ce was found in the trivalent state with its proportion increasing as the particle size decreased. Doping of the Zr 0.1 Ce 0.9 O 2 nanotubes with Pd resulted in a considerably higher amount of Ce 3+ that was not affected significantly by the reduction process. The spectra recorded at the Pd-L 3 -edge demonstrated that Pd was in a higher oxidation state compared to metallic Pd (as deduced from the position of the absorption edge and the intensity of the white line). The results indicated that Pd was incorporated in the nanotube structure. Ce-L 3 -and Pd-L 3 -edge XANES recorded in situ during heating under reducing conditions revealed that as the temperature increased, the percentage of Ce 3+ increased but at much higher amount in the presence of Pd.
The formation of PdO nanoparticles in the pores of various medium-or large-pore zeolites by Pd ion exchange and heating was reported by Park et al. [153]. These materials are effective catalysts for methane combustion. Pd-K-edge EXAFS revealed the formation of PdO and Pd particles. The size of the zeolite pores was found to control the size of the PdO particles, thus affecting their catalytic activity.
Johnston-Peck et al. [154] studied CeO x particles (with size 5-45 nm) on TiO 2 support by Ce-L 2,3 -edge XANES. The position of the L-edges was used for the determination of the oxidation state of Ce. It was found that a large fraction of Ce was trivalent. This was an indication that the incorporation of ceria on the titania surface results in charge transfer between O and Ce. Furthermore, comparison of the spectra recorded in the TEY and FLY modes, which are characterized by different information depths, revealed a different value of the Ce 3+ /Ce4 concentration ratio.
The results indicate that Ce exists in a reduced state not at the surface but probably near the ceriaÀtitania interface. Variations in the oxidation state of Ce in Pt-CeO x catalysts were also observed in the Ce-L 3 -edge XANES [155]. More specifically, synthesis of mixed CeO 2 /Pt catalysts resulted in the formation of Ce 3+ species although Ce in pure CeO 2 is tetravalent. After immersing the Pt-CeO x in H 2 SO 4 solution for oxygen reduction catalysis, the edge jump decreased to approximately 6 % implying the dissolution of CeO x . The XANES spectra revealed that only Ce 3+ remained in the sample.
Cu-Al-O x catalysts of the water-gas shift reaction in proton-exchange membrane fuel cells were studied for daily start-up/shut-down operation [156]. The Cu-Al-O x catalysts were investigated with in situ Cu-K-edge XAFS spectroscopy. The acquisition time was 60 s and the spectra were recorded at 33 s intervals. Cu foil, Cu 2 O, and CuO were used as reference compounds for the 0, +1, and +2 oxidation state of Cu, respectively. Cu-K-edge XANES and EXAFS spectra revealed that during the start-up/shut-down-like operation, oxidation of Cu metal to Cu 2 O and then reduction to Cu take place. However, variations in the amount of Cu + during the first and the second cycle were observed between the coprecipitated and impregnated catalysts. The results were discussed in combination with the particle size, as deduced from the coordination numbers. In a perspective article, Rodriguez et al. [157] present applications of time-resolved in situ XAFS for the study of catalysts which combine Cu, Au, or Pt with oxides such as ZnO, CeO 2 , TiO 2 , CeO x /TiO 2 , and Fe 2 O 3 . Under reaction conditions most water-gas shift catalysts undergo chemical transformations that can be easily detected by XAFS spectroscopy.

Fe Oxides and Other Magnetic Nanoparticles
Nanosized Fe oxides find various applications due to their magnetic, electronic, photonic, and optical properties. Magnetic nanoparticles have been a subject of intensive research because of their applications in nano-diagnosis and nanotherapy. Magnetite (Fe 3 O 4 ) and maghemite (γ-Fe 2 O 3 ) have attracted particular interest because they are ferromagnetic and biocompatible while they can be easily removed from the body via natural routes. The chemical formula of Fe 3 O 4 is often written as (Fe 2 O 3 ) Á (FeO) in order to indicate the coexistence of Fe 3+ (which occupies tetrahedral and octahedral sites) and Fe 2+ (in octahedral coordination). In maghemite (γ-Fe 2 O 3 ), which also adopts the spinel structure, Fe 2+ is oxidized to Fe 3+ and the charge neutrality is maintained by the presence of vacancies in octahedral sites. α-Fe 2 O 3 (hematite) is a nonmagnetic allotropic form of trivalent Fe with rhombohedral crystal structure. One phenomenon that is observed in nanosized Fe oxides is the apparent oxidation of the magnetite nanoparticles. Corrias et al. [158] used XAFS to study the effect of the nanoparticle size and oxidation degree (by sequential injection of an oxidizer during synthesis), on the structure of monodisperse iron oxide nanoparticles. The characteristic pre-edge peak was quite pronounced in the XANES spectra of Fe 3 O 4 and γ-Fe 2 O 3 , where Fe was both tetrahedrally and octahedrally coordinated. Its intensity was lower in structures where Fe was only octahedrally coordinated, for example, FeO and α-Fe 2 O 3 . XRD and TEM revealed that polycrystalline nanoparticles, consisting of FeO and a spinel phase, were formed at low oxidant amounts, whereas single-crystalline spinel nanoparticles were obtained by increasing the oxidation degree. EXAFS analysis disclosed that in nanoparticles of 10 and 14.5 nm size, the relative amount of the spinel phase was 76 % and 58 %. Single-crystalline spinel nanoparticles were obtained by increasing the degree of oxidation. In the polycrystalline colloids, spontaneous slow oxidation takes place, whereas the larger nanocrystals oxidize more readily. Finally, in the 8 nm particles, the spinel structure was a mixture of mainly Fe 3 O 4 and γ-Fe 2 O 3 , whereas in the 13 nm crystals, the γ-Fe 2 O 3 phase was dominant. In another investigation of Fe 3 O 4 as an electrode material for Li-ion batteries, Menard et al. [159] applied Fe-K-edge XAFS spectroscopy in order to study size-related effects in magnetite nanoparticles. In the Fe-K-edge XANES spectra shown in Fig. 4.22, both the position of the absorption edge and the pre-edge peak shift toward higher energies with decreasing particle size. Using the spectra of reference Fe oxides, the position of the absorption edge and the pre-edge peak were used for the determination of the oxidation state of Fe in the magnetic nanoparticles. The results revealed that upon exposure to air, a number of Fe 3+ surface atoms oxidized to Fe 2+ . This oxidation was held responsible for the increase in the discharge capacity of Fe 3 O 4 electrodes. Similar shifts in the position of the absorption edge of γ-Fe 2 O 3 compared to Fe 3 O 4 were observed by Mendoza Zélis et al. [160].
Piquer et al. [161] applied Fe-K-and L 2,3 -edge XANES and XMCD in order to study iron oxide nanoparticles synthesized by various methods. The problem addressed was whether oxidation of Fe is better explained by the formation of separate Fe 3 O 4 and γ-Fe 2 O 3 phases that coexist in the nanoparticles, or if a single, non-stoichiometric phase is formed throughout the nanoparticles. L 2,3 -edge XANES and XMCD analysis could not easily discriminate between the γ-Fe 2 O 3 and Fe 3 O 4 phases and could not provide accurate determination of the coexistence of the two phases in a sample. The Fe-K-edge XANES spectra of the nanoparticles had a profile intermediate to that of bulk magnetite and maghemite. The nanoparticle size rather than the synthesis method appeared to affect the profile of the XANES spectra. However, the linear combination method for the fitting of the spectra from the nanoparticles, as a weighted average of the spectra of bulk magnetite and maghemite, did not work properly. MXAN simulations indicated that a single phase non-stoichiometric oxide was grown with crystal structure possessing a cell parameter lying in-between those of the pure stoichiometric magnetite and maghemite oxides.
Surfactant effects on the morphological, structural, and magnetic properties of iron oxide nanoparticles produced by coprecipitation were investigated by Filippousi et al. [162]. The use of the different surfactants resulted in nanoparticles with different sizes (7-12 nm), different unit cell parameters (as determined by XRD), and different Fe oxidation states that took values in-between those of γ-Fe 2 O 3 and Fe 3 O 4 . The oxidation state was determined from the position of the absorption edge in the Fe-K-edge spectra. EXAFS analysis revealed that the nanoparticles adopt the spinel structure, while the Fe-O distance was slightly smaller compared to the corresponding value in magnetite, in consistence with the increased Fe oxidation state detected by XANES. Bora et al. [163] used Fe-K-edge XANES in order to study the effect of different heat treatment temperatures (250-900 C) during the synthesis of Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles. From the variations in the pre-edge peak characteristics, i.e., intensity under the pre-edge peak and relative contribution of the various components, they deduced that at low temperatures maghemite (γ-Fe 2 O 3 ) was the dominant phase, whereas as the temperature increased, the oxidation state of Fe increased and hematite (α-Fe 2 O 3 ) dominated.
γ-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles coated with Cu were studied by means of Fe-and Cu-L 2,3edge XANES [164]. The XANES spectra revealed that the particles consisted of γ-Fe 2 O 3 coated with a mixture of Cu and Cu 2+ consistent with the formation of CuO layer at the interface of Cu and γ-Fe 2 O 3 . Taking into account the XRD and TEM results, it was concluded that the thickness of this layer was very small and was consistent with the formation of bonds between O atoms of γ-Fe 2 O 3 with the Cu coating. Temperature-dependent XMCD at the Fe-L 2,3 -and Cu-L 2,3 -edges indicated that the Cu coating altered the surface anisotropy of γ-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles and apparently modified the Fe(octahedral)-O-Fe(tetrahedral) super-exchange. Variations observed in the nanomagnetism as a function of the Cu shell thickness were also discussed. The effect of a polypyrrole shell, which covers Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles [165], and oleic acid coating of iron oxide nanoparticles, in the oxidation state of Fe [166] was also investigated using XAFS. Porous iron oxide fabricated on a wood template were also investigated using Fe-K-edge EXAFS that verified the formation of α-Fe 2 O 3 [167].
Bulk NiO is an antiferromagnetic material. However, magnetic behavior is observed when the NiO particle size is reduced down to the nanoscale. NiO nanoparticles with size 2-10 nm were studied by means of Ni-K-edge XAFS [168]. The EXAFS spectra revealed that the coordination number in the first nearest neighboring shell (Ni-O) was not affected by the particle size. Reduction of the coordination number in the second nearest neighboring shell (Ni-Ni) from 11 to 9.6 was observed as the particle size was reduced from 9 to 2.5 nm. Size-dependent variations were not observed in the XANES spectra indicating that the oxidation state was Ni 2+ , i.e., as in the bulk. Another approach for the analysis of the EXAFS spectra of NiO nanoparticles was presented in Refs. [169,170]. The relaxed atomic positions in the NiO nanoparticles that were used to simulate the EXAFS spectra were calculated with molecular dynamics. Several thousands of atomic configurations were adopted in order to take into account configurational averaging in the EXAFS signal.
Another family of magnetic materials is the magnetic spinel ferrites which are described with the general chemical formula M x Fe 3Àx O 4 , where M=Fe, Co, Mn, Ni, or Zn. They have biological applications such as thermal activation therapy, hyperthermia, biosensing, drug delivery, and magnetic resonance imaging. Addition of other metals in the structure of Fe 3 O 4 allows for the modification of the magnetic properties of the nanoparticles. The distribution of the metal ions in the tetrahedral and octahedral sites of the spinel structure depends on the radii, the oxidation state, and the electronic configuration of the ions. Another important parameter that affects the properties of the nanoparticles is the inversion parameter, i, which is defined as the number of divalent cations in octahedral sites. Co-K-and Fe-K-edge EXAFS was applied for the study of silica-coated CoFe 2 O 4 nanoparticles [171]. The Fe-Kedge XANES spectra revealed that the CoFe 2 O 4 nanoparticles adopt the structure of the reference CoFe 2 O 4 material, i.e., an inverse spinel structure with the Fe 3+ ions occupies all the tetrahedral sites and half of the octahedral sites, while Fe 2+ occupies a fraction of the remaining octahedral sites. The Co-K-edge XANES spectra of the unleached nanoparticles disclosed that a portion of the Co ions occupied tetrahedral sites. Leaching, which took place spontaneously after dilution in water, resulted in a spectrum similar to that of the reference CoFe 2 O 4 sample. EXAFS verified the XANES observations, i.e., variations in the Co bonding environment that occurred upon leaching. In the unleached nanoparticles, Co occupied tetrahedral sites, whereas after leaching it occupied octahedral sites. These leaching-induced variations in the inversion degree were held responsible for the changes in the magnetic behavior of the nanoparticles.
Co-substituted ferrite nanoparticles with size 5-6 nm and Co content varying from 0 to 0.94 were studied by means of XAFS [172]. XANES revealed that the oxidation state of Fe and Co was 3+ and 2+, respectively. From the characteristics of the pre-edge peak, it was deduced that a larger number of Fe than Co atoms occupy tetrahedral sites. EXAFS analysis demonstrated that although the Co content was varied considerably, the ratio of the Co ions occupying tetrahedral and octahedral sites did not vary and the inversion degree was found 0.7 for all the samples.
The size effect on the structural properties of Mn ferrites has been also investigated using XAFS [173]. The size of the nanoparticles took values in the range 3-6 nm and the Mn/Fe ratio varied from 1.65 to 1.76. The position of the absorption edge and the pre-edge peak characteristics in the XANES spectra were used for the determination of the oxidation state. It was found that Fe adopts the spinel structure with higher occupation of tetrahedral sites by Fe atoms which were predominantly in the oxidation state 3+. A significant fraction of the Mn ions was also found in the 3+ oxidation state as it was deduced from the Mn-K-edge XANES spectra. For the EXAFS analysis, the structural formula of stoichiometric Mn ferrite can be written as [Mn 1Ài Fe i ] A [Mn i Fe 2Ài ] B O 4 where A and B denote tetrahedral and octahedral sites, respectively. For normal and inverse spinel, i takes the values 0 and 1, respectively. For the EXAFS analysis, nearest neighbor configurations of both the tetrahedral and octahedral sites, with proper weighting factors, should be taken into account. The inversion degree in the nanoparticles was found to range between 0.57 and 0.60 and it was lower compared to the value 0.7 that was determined for the bulk sample. Stoichiometric Mn ferrites with size of approximately 8 nm were also studied by means of XAFS [174]. Fe was found trivalent, whereas the oxidation state of Mn varied between 2+ and 3+. Partial oxidation of the Mn 2+ , which was controlled by the used Mn precursor, was detected and resulted in the reduction of the inversion degree from 0.42 to 0.22. The size effect on the inversion degree of nanosized Ni, Co, and Zn ferrites was investigated by Nordhei et al. [175] for nanoparticle size ranging from 4 to 25 nm and by Hellner Nilsen et al. [176] for nanoparticle size ranging from 39 to 105 nm.

Nanoceramics
ZrO 2 -based ceramics exhibit excellent electrical and mechanical properties which are attributed to the small, usually in the nanoscale, grain size. Fábregas and Lamas [177] studied ZrO 2 -Y 2 O 3 and ZrO 2 -CeO 2 powders, synthesized by gel combustion, at the Zr-K-and Y-K-edges. During the synthesis, various fuels (amino acids or citric acid) were added in the Zr and Y precursor solution to form gels. The ceramic powders were produced after combustion. Direct comparison of the Zr-K-edge spectra of the powders with reference compounds revealed that when amino acids were used as fuels, the bonding configuration was similar to the ZrOCl 2 precursor, whereas when citric acid was used, the XANES spectra did not have any similarities with the reference compounds. The spectra of the precursor gels, when amino acids were used as fuels, were fitted using three O paths for the first nearest neighboring shell (the total coordination number ranged from 6.9 to 7.5) and one Zr-Zr path (the coordination number ranged from 2 to 3). This model was similar to the one used for the ZrOCl 2 precursor. For the precursor gels that contained citric acid as fuel, the more symmetric model of cubic ZrO 2 was used. Contrary to the Zr atoms which were found chelated, Y atoms had one neighboring shell consisting of eight oxygen atoms at a distance of 2.35-2.39 Å

Nanocomposites
Nanocomposites are multiphase materials where one of the phases has one, two, or three dimensions smaller that 100 nm. The mechanical, electrical, optical, and thermal properties of the nanocomposites differ significantly from those of the constituent phases. In the following, representative applications of XAFS spectroscopies for the study of nanocomposites with improved mechanical, wear, and irradiation resistance and tribological properties will be discussed.
Oxide dispersion-strengthened (ODS) ferritic steels, which contain high concentration of nanosized oxide particles, are characterized by enhanced resistance to irradiation and thus are promising materials for applications in nuclear technology, for example, in reactors and in the waste incineration process. They are also candidates for CO 2 -free production of hydrogen and other applications such as in corrosive environments under high temperatures. ODS ferrite steel samples with 0.25-0.5 wt% Y 2 O 3 were studied by He et al. [178]. The samples were prepared by mechanical alloying of Fe-13.5% Cr-2%W pre-alloyed powders with 0.3 wt% Y 2 O 3 and 0-0.5 wt% TiH 2 powders. The samples were studied after mechanical alloying and consolidation with hot isostatic pressing. The synthesis conditions were expected to affect strongly the mechanical properties due to the varying degree of  The structure of the spectrum above the absorption edge is smeared out denoting that the Y 2 O 3 particles lack long-range order. From the linear combination fit of the XANES spectra, it was deduced that less than 15 % of Y was in the metallic form. The XANES spectra of the compacted samples revealed that the oxidation state of Y was 3+ and indicated the formation of new Y-oxide phases. The EXAFS analysis of the powder samples disclosed that Y was in the form of Y 2 O 3 . The fact that the calculated coordination numbers are smaller is attributed to the plastic deformation introduced by the mechanical alloying. In the compacted Ti-free samples, YCrO 3 and Y 2 O 3 phases were found to coexist. In the compacted samples that contained Ti, mixed Y-Ti oxide phases were taken into account to fit the EXAFS spectra.
Precipitation-hardened Al alloys find applications in the aircraft industry. Staab et al. [179] applied XAFS for the study of nanoprecipitate phases in Al alloys. Such precipitates are held responsible for the hardening of Al alloys similar to the case of steel. However, in Al alloys synthesized by solution heating followed by quenching, such precipitates appeared to be formed after storage. The formation of precipitates in the alloys plays an important role in the increase of their strength even if the size of the precipitate is smaller than 1 nm. However, precipitates of such small sizes cannot be detected with HRTEM and/or XRD. Cu-K-edge XAFS was applied for the study of AlCu and AlCuMg alloys containing 1.7 and 1.87 at.% Cu, respectively. The latter also contained 1.78 at.% Mg. The Cu-K-edge measurements were conducted at À40 C after an increasing-decreasing temperature cycle, a process that simulates natural aging. In regard to the analysis of the XAFS spectra, FEFF simulations were performed using a cluster that contained more than 87 atoms and assuming the Debye model for the estimation of the Debye-Waller factors. The simulations of the AlCu alloy spectra revealed that in the as-quenched state, isolated Cu atoms as well as Cu atoms participating in the formation of Guinier-Preston zones (Cu precipitates in the form of monoatomic platelets) existed, whereas after heat treatment the Al 2 Cu phase (Θ-phase) was formed. The Cu-K-edge XAFS spectra of the AlCuMg alloy were fitted to identify variations with aging (storage time). As the aging time increased (from 8 min to 8 h), the distance between Cu and its neighboring atoms decreased, exhibiting relaxation. FEFF simulations revealed that the S-phase was formed after heat treatment.
Transition metal carbides find applications in wear-and oxidation-resistant protective coatings and in low-friction solid lubricants. The applications are based on the nanocrystalline/amorphous-C nanocomposite structure. Furlan et al. [180]   had similar characteristics with the Ni-L 2,3 -edge spectra shown in Fig. 4.24. However, crystal field-induced splitting of the L 2 and L 3 peaks was observed in all studied samples and was attributed to the formation of an amorphous FeC y carbide phase. Variations in the relative intensity of the L 3 and L 2 peaks revealed variations in the Fe ionicity in the FeC y phase. The C-K-edge spectra was also found to depend on x with the relative intensity of the π* to the total π* and σ* intensity decreasing with x. This variation has been attributed to the reduction of sp 2 (C=C) and sp 1 hybridization in the amorphous C-phase and the C 2p-Fe 3d hybridized states in the iron carbide phase. TiBC/amorphous-C nanocomposite films grown by sputtering from TiC:TiB 2 and graphite targets, with varying B/C ratios, were studied by means of Ti-K-edge XAFS [182]. The XANES spectra had intermediate characteristics between those of hexagonal-TiB 2 and fcc-TiC. Incorporation of C in the TiB 2 phase was detected. As the C content increased, further peaks in the Fourier transform gained intensity, indicating that TiC and/or TiB x C y phases were formed. TiN/Ni nanocomposite films were studied by Pinakidou et al. [183] with XAFS at the N-K-and Ni-K-edge. The samples consisted of TiN nanocrystals covered by an intergranular Ni phase and attracted interest due to superhardness and high chemical stability. They were prepared by sputtering and the Ni content was below 21.5 at.%. The N-K-edge NEXAFS did not reveal any differences among the samples with different Ni content indicating that the TiN structure was not affected by the Ni concentration. The EXAFS analysis at the Ni-K-edge disclosed that differences in the chemical composition affected strongly the coordination environment of Ni. More specifically, the number of Ni and Ti atoms bonded to Ni increased as the Ni content increased, and the total coordination number of Ni (with Ni and Ti atoms) increased with the [Ni]/[N] concentration ratio. The results indicated that the Ni atoms belong to a Ni matrix and also form bonds with Ti atoms in the TiN nanocrystals. TiN/Cu nanocomposites prepared by sputtering were also studied by means of Cu-K-edge EXAFS [184]. The authors reported that when the Cu content increased from 24 to 53 %, the total coordination number of Cu in the first nearest neighboring shell (comprised of Cu and Ti neighbors) increased from 6 to 11. The number of Ti neighboring atoms did not change significantly. The results demonstrated that as the Cu content increased, the Cu-Cu bonding became predominant indicating the formation of metallic Cu in-between the TiN nanocrystals.

6.5
Carbon-Based Nanomaterials Carbon nanomaterials, for example, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), fullerene, and nanodiamond films, have tunable optical, electronic, and mechanical properties and are attractive for the fabrication of micro-and optoelectronic devices, chemical sensors, composite materials, and medical implants, as well as in renewable energy and environmental technologies. Recently, graphene, a single layer of sp 2 bonded C, attracted a lot of interests as a promising material for the fabrication of the nextgeneration electronic devices. C-K-edge NEXAFS spectroscopy is widely applied for the study of carbon-based nanomaterials. Examples of such applications are discussed in the following.

Carbon Nanotubes
Carbon nanotubes are hexagonal arrays of carbon atoms rolled in such a way to form long, thin, hollow cylinders. They can be single-walled (SWNT) or multi-walled (MWNT) with their length and diameter varying from few hundred nanometers to several microns and from 1 to few hundred nanometers, respectively [185]. Information on their amorphous character and/or sp 3 content, the degree of alignment, the effectiveness of functionalization processes, and the presence of defects can be provided by NEXAFS, which is applied extensively. Functionalization refers to the attachment of atoms, molecules, or aggregates on the surface of the CNTs in order to reduce their chemical inertness. XAFS spectroscopy is also applied in intercalated CNTs in order to study the orientation, symmetry, and/or strain state of the intercalated compound. Due to the small binding energy of the K electrons in the carbon atom, acquisition of C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra necessitates ultrahigh vacuum conditions. Electron yield detectors (channeltrons) are mainly used for the detection of the total or partial electron yield (see also Sect. 4). For the energy calibration, due to monochromator shifts, the π* resonance of HOPG at 285.35 eV is commonly used (see Sect. 5).
The electronic structure of the nanotubes is similar to that of graphite, and thus their C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra exhibit strong similarities (see Fig. 4.14). More specifically, the sharp resonance at 285.4 eV (i.e., before the absorption edge), which is detected in the spectra of C-nanotubes, is attributed to 1s ! π* transitions. In addition to that, the broad band, with a prominent resonance at approximately 291.5 eV (i.e., above the absorption edge) is attributed to 1s ! σ* transitions [13]. In the energy range between the π* and σ* resonances, absorption attributed to defects, i.e., bonding of C with O and/or H, is observed. Broadening of the π* resonance in the spectra of MWNTs is attributed to the bending of the graphene layers that induces splitting of the π 2p z conduction sub-band [186]. Furthermore, variations in the width of the π* and σ* resonances, related to the synthesis process and the presence of defects, were observed. Fleming et al. [187] applied C-K-edge NEXAFS on SWNTs self-assembled on Si(100) in order to study the intensity variations of the π* resonance for various sample orientations and angles of incidence. In general, the linear polarization of the SR beam is employed in C-K-edge NEXAFS in order to study the orientation of the CNTs. Aligned CNTs have potential applications as field emitters and in high strength materials. Li et al. applied angleresolved C-K-edge NEXAFS to study the orientation of single-walled nanotubes (SWNTs), with diameter equal to 2 nm, that were vertically aligned on a Si wafer [188]. The spectra were collected at incidence angles ranging from grazing to normal to the sample surface. As discussed in Sect. 5, the intensity of the π* resonance is proportional to cos 2 δ, where δ is the angle between the electric field vector of the polarized incident beam and the direction of the maximum electron density that corresponds to the molecular orbitals. The π* orbital is considered normal to the hexagonal honeycomb structure, i.e., to the CNT wall. For the σ* orbital, a planar distribution of electron density on the hexagonal lattice plane is taken into account. In CNTs, the σ* orbital can be modeled as having two contributions, one parallel to the tube axis, σ || , and one tangential to the tube perimeter, σ ⊥ (see inset of Fig. 4.25). The authors verified the well-oriented character of the nanotubes by the angular dependence of the π* and σ* resonances, which was in agreement with the theoretical predictions. The application of C-K-edge spectroscopy for the determination of the CNT orientation is also discussed in Ref. [189]. In order to assess the degree of order in the orientation of the CNTs, an order parameter (OP), which is also defined as dichroic ratio, is often adopted. The OP is defined as OP = (I ⊥ À I || )/(I ⊥ + I || ) where I ⊥ and I || are the π* resonance intensities at normal and grazing incidence [190]. Absolute values close to unity indicate high order.
Another important property of the CNTs that renders them suitable for applications is functionalization, i.e., the attachment of atoms, molecules, or aggregates on the surface of the tube which is otherwise chemically inert. Functionalization of the CNTs results in improvement of their dispersion in various matrices to form composite materials and expands their applications in nanoelectronics, hydrogen storage, bioengineering, etc. Depending on the required CNT properties for specific applications, different functionalization, obtained via different processing steps, is necessary [191]. Functionalization of SWNT via oxidation (e.g., wet air oxidation of ozone/H 2 O 2 -treated tubes) revealed that the intensity of the π* resonance decreased and additional peaks due to C=O (σ*) and C-O (π*) appeared in the energy range 287-290 eV [190]. Functionalization is also important for the application of CNTs as heterogeneous catalyst supports, for example, in hydrogen storage in fuel cellse.g., proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (see Sect. 6.3.2). Carbon-based materials have several unique properties as catalyst supports compared to oxides, for example, dissolution resistance in high-temperature aqueous solutions, chemical resistance, engineering of the chemical properties by different ways of functionalization, and electrical conductivity. The employment of CNTs as catalyst supports for Pt nanoparticles and improvement of their uniform dispersion necessitates oxidation of the CNTs which creates oxygen-containing surface groups that act as absorption sites for the Pt nanoparticles. Wang et al. [192] studied the effect of different oxygencontaining groups on MWNT-supported Pt catalysts. The C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra of the MWNTs after treatment with HNO 3 revealed the formation of C-O bonds. More specifically, the π* and σ* transitions of C-O appear at 287.6 and 288.2 eV, respectively (i.e., in-between the π* and σ* transitions of C-C). Annealing in He atmosphere at 1273 K resulted in partial removal of the C-O bonds. The same trend was observed in the O-K-edge spectra where the O content can be determined from the edge jump height. Comparison of the C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra recorded under different PEY retarding voltages and in the FLY mode revealed that the oxygen-containing groups were mainly located on the surface of the MWNT. The authors studied also the spectra recorded at the L 3 edge of Pt. The spectra of the Pt-loaded MWNTs (non-treated, functionalized with HNO 3 , and subsequently annealed) were compared with the spectra of a Pt foil. In the spectra of the MWNTs, the white line (see Sect. 6.1.1) had lower intensity compared to that of the Pt foil and the absorption edge was shifted to lower energies indicating charge transfer between the Pt cluster and the MWNT. The Pt-L 3 -edge EXAFS spectra verify that Pt was in the form of metallic nanoparticles. The authors estimated the size of the nanoclusters from the average coordination number.
Contrary to applications where functionalization is necessary, there exist a number of other applications where an increased inertness is important. For example, Brzhezinskaya et al. [193] applied N-K-and F-K-edge NEXAFS for the study of fluorination of MWNTs. The authors compared the fluorinated MWNTs with HOPG and white graphite fluoride (WGF). The C-K-edge spectra of the MWNTs that were in powder form exhibited strong similarities with the spectrum of HOPG. More specifically, upon fluorination, the π* resonance progressively lost intensity (see Fig. 4.26) and the spectrum became gradually similar to that of the WGF. The intensity of the π* resonance decreased as the F content increased, implying that the F atoms were attached perpendicular to the graphene layer and they did not replace C atoms in the honeycomb structure. Contrary to the C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra, the F-K-edge spectra did not exhibit variations with the degree of fluorination. Thus, the interaction of the F atoms with the MWNTs proceeded through covalent attachment of F atoms to the tube skeleton, without its destruction, although hybridization changed from sp 2 to sp 3 . The effect of thermal annealing on defluorination was also reported in the same paper.
The hydrogenation efficiency of SWNTs and their potential for applications in H storage was accessed with C-K-edge NEXAFS [194]. It was found that upon hydrogenation, the intensity of the π* resonance decreased and spectral features due to C-H bonding appeared. The ability of the liquid solvent SOCl 2 to remove the oxidized groups from SWNTs has been also studied [195]. Direct comparison of the C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra of pristine and SOCl 2 -treated nanotubes revealed that the bands attributed to the π* states of C=O (288.5 eV) and σ* states of C-O (289.5 eV), which appear in-between the π* and σ* resonances, disappear after the treatment.
Another important issue in CNTs concerns their doping, i.e., the incorporation of atoms in the hexagonal lattice. It has been reported that nitrogen doping increases the CNT reactivity toward deposition of Pt nanoparticles for catalytic applications. N-doped CNTs were studied by means of C-K-edge NEXAFS [196]. A comparison Low-pressure radio-frequency glow discharge was applied for the ex situ (postdeposition) N-doping of vertically aligned MWNTs [197]. Nitrogen can be incorporated in the graphitic network in various ways, e.g., substitutional, pyridinic, intercalated N 2 between the graphite layers, located in nonplanar sp 3 sites, or chemisorbed. From the angular dependence of the C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra, it was deduced that the vertical orientation of the nanotubes was preserved. In the N-K-edge spectra, three π* resonances existed that evidenced the presence of various C-N bonds (pyridine-like, cyanic structure and substitutional, the graphite lattice). Their angular dependence revealed that N replaced C in the graphite rings, whereas a fraction of the N atoms formed cyanic structures. Annealing at 800 C promoted incorporation of N in the graphitic planes and led in the formation of C-O/ C=O bonds.
Intercalation of various compounds is also possible in CNTs. Encapsulation of Co-phthalocyanine (CoPc) in CNTs was studied by Schulte et al. [198]. Phthalocyanines comprise a group of blue-green pigments which can incorporate a number of different metals in their structure. They exhibit strong optical absorption and they are used in organic photovoltaic devices. Encapsulation of CoPc in CNTs permits the formation of one-dimensional molecular arrays that allow control of their optical and magnetic properties. Although transmission electron microscopy (TEM) can provide an image of the CNTs and verify the encapsulation of CoPc, the ordering of these planar molecules cannot be verified. In order to explore the N bonding geometry in the molecule, the orientation of the CoPc molecules was studied by means of N-K-edge NEXAFS spectroscopy (see Fig. 4.28). The lower unoccupied molecular orbital π* is oriented perpendicular to the plane of the CoPc molecule, and since the initial state of the transition is a 1s (with spherical symmetry), it can be represented by a vector Ο ! normal to the molecule plane. The angular dependence of the resonance's intensity was studied as a function of two angles that determine the orientation of Ο ! relative to the sample surface, two angles that determine the orientation (inclination and rolling) of the molecule in the nanotube and the angle of incidence of the beam. These equations were simplified on the basis of microscopy observations for the orientation of the nanotubes on the substrate. In this way, the remaining dependence was on the angle of incidence θ and the angle ν formed by the planar molecule and the axis of the nanotube (see inset in Fig. 4.28). The theoretical curves that demonstrate the normalized θ-dependence of the resonance intensity using as parameter the ν angle are shown in Fig. 4.28. From the location of the experimentally determined intensities of the π* resonance on these curves, the authors determined a ν angle equal to 54 AE 5 . RuO 2 -coated CNTs are functional nanocomposites that have potential applications as supercapacitors, in fuel cells, catalysts, and biosensors. The interaction of the RuO 2 with MWNT was studied with C-K-, O-K-and Ru-L 3 -edge NEXAFS by Zhou et al. [199]. The results implied that the structure of the nanotube was not disturbed, Ru-O-C bonds were formed between the RuO 2 coating and the nanotube, and charge transfer from the RuO 2 to the nanotube took place. Spectromicroscopic techniques were also applied for the study of CNTs. Felten et al. [200,201] combined scanning transmission X-ray microscopy (STXM) and NEXAFS with a spatial resolution better than 40 nm (which was achieved using a Fresnel zone plate), for the study of individual MWNTs. The transmitted signal was measured with a single-photon counter using a phosphor converter and a highperformance photomultiplier tube. The STXM image can be recorded with beam energy that corresponds to a specific feature of the C 1s spectrum, for example, the 1s ! π* or 1s ! σ* transitions for sp 2 -hybridized C atoms. Comparison of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images with STXM reveals the type of the CNTs existing in the sample and can be used for easier selection of the sample spot for the acquisition of the NEXAFS spectra, for example, MWNT, carbon nanoparticles, or carbon support grid. In the spectra of the MWNTs, the width of the π* resonance is smaller compared to the nanoparticles. The different chemical components identified by NEXAFS spectroscopy can be appropriately used to construct chemical maps that reveal the location and amount of each phase in the map. The authors discuss also the differences in the NEXAFS spectra of nanotubes prepared under different synthesis conditions. MWNTs selectively damaged by ion bombardment were also studied through spectromicroscopy by employing linear dichroism, i.e., the angular dependence of the NEXAFS signal. More specifically, the intensity of the π* resonance is maximized (minimized) when the nanotubes are oriented with their axis perpendicular, I ⊥ (parallel, I || ), to the polarization vector of the electric field of the beam. The ratio I R = I || /I ⊥ varies with the defect content of the nanotubes. For a perfect nanotube and for 100 % linearly polarized SR beam, I R approaches 0, whereas when the tube loses its sp 2 character through bonding with other tubes or loosing C atoms and buckling, I R increases [202]. Irradiation of nanotubes with Ga + ions resulted in a higher value of I R which increased further with the ion fluence. Furthermore, thicker tubes appeared more resistant to irradiation-induced amorphization.

Graphene and Graphene Oxide
Angle-resolved C-K-edge NEXAFS is extensively used for the characterization of graphene. Zhang et al. [203] applied angle-resolved C-K-edge NEXAFS spectroscopy for the study of a single layer of graphene on SiO 2 . Although the intensity of the π* resonance (285.5 eV) exhibited a linear dependence on cos 2 θ, where θ is the angle of incidence relative to the sample surface, it did not vanish completely at normal incidence indicating significant rippling or corrugation of the layer. Similar observations were reported by Lee et al. [204] for the orientation of a single graphene layer that was grown on Cu and transferred to a SiO 2 /Si substrate. Although the dichroic ratio of the as-grown layer on Cu was À0.97 (i.e., very close to À1 for a perfectly oriented and corrugation-free graphene layer), after transfer to the SiO 2 /Si substrate, it reduced to À0.72. Residuals of the PMMA used for the transfer can be easily detected in the C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra as a strong peak at 288.6 eV. Graphene epitaxially grown on a Ni (111) substrate was also found to be corrugation or ripple-free. In the same paper, angular-dependent measurements were also performed to study the orientation of terephthalic acid molecules on graphene [205]. It should be pointed out that special care for the subtraction of the C-Kedge signal of graphene form that of the terephthalic acid was taken. In addition to the fact that metal substrates, such as Ni, are suitable for the growth of good quality graphene, certain metal/grapheme systems have the potential for other applications as well. For example, Ni(111)/graphene structures are promising for potential applications in spintronics: C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra of graphene on Ni (111) are shown in Fig. 4.29 for various angles of incidence along with the spectrum of a reference graphite sample [206]. The NEXAFS spectra also provide information on the interaction of graphene with the metal atoms. Thus, considerable broadening of the σ* and π* resonances was observed in the case of the graphene/Ni (111) and was attributed to the strong orbital hybridization and electron sharing at the graphene/Ni interface. A small shoulder observed in the spectra at 283.7 eV (i.e., below the π* resonance) was associated with lowering of the Fermi level due to charge transfer. An additional characteristic is the splitting of the π* resonance (two peaks at 285.5 and 287.1 eV). The splitting was attributed to hybridization of the C p z with Ni threedimensional orbital at the interface. In the same paper magnetization of Ni ( 111) was studied with XMCD measurements. Intercalation of one Fe monolayer between graphene and Ni (111)  [207] does not result in the elimination of the second peak in the π* region. On the contrary, intercalation of Al causes elimination of the second peak indicating that this thin Al layer effectively decouples the graphene layer from the Ni (111) substrate, thus leading to the nearly free-standing behavior of graphene with small electron doping [208]. Similar splitting, which has been observed in graphene grown on Cu, is less pronounced in double graphene layers compared to single ones [204]. Voloshina et al. [209] applied simulation of the NEXAFS spectra, with various theoretical models, in order to understand the interaction mechanisms between the graphene and the metal.
Formation of interfaces between graphene and ultrathin dielectrics is important in a variety of microelectronic devices. However such interfacing may affect the transport properties of graphene. Schultz et al. [210] employed angle-resolved C-K-edge NEXAFS for the study of graphene on SiO 2 with TiO 2 , ZrO 2 , HfO 2 , or TiN overlayers. The angular dependence of the spectra of the graphene layer on SiO 2 revealed its good orientation. However, deposition of a dielectric on top of graphene reduced the anisotropy of the spectra due to introduction of defects and corrugations. The authors compared the intensity of the π* resonance for the various dielectrics and proposed that strong covalent bonding took place when a TiN overlayer was used, while only charge redistribution occurred in the case of a HfO 2 overlayer.
Graphene is a zero-gap semiconductor and therefore doping is applied to achieve gap opening. n-and p-doped graphene is a promising material for applications in biosensing, Li-batteries, and fuel cells [211]. Nitrogen is an n-type dopant, but it forms various types of defects when incorporated in graphene. N-K-edge NEXAFS spectra of N-doped graphene (pristine N-doped graphene on Ni (111), decoupled with gold intercalation and quasi-free standing after post-synthesis annealing) are shown in Fig. 4.30. Doping of graphene with N was achieved by introducing NH 3 in the gas flow during the chemical vapor deposition growth of graphene on Cu substrates. As shown in Fig. 4.30, three characteristic peaks appear in the spectra. Peak C, at ~401 eV, that is detected in the spectra of the annealed, Au-intercalated N-doped graphene was attributed to N 1 s ! π* of N in the graphitic environment. This particular peak gains intensity at grazing incidence. The angular dependence of peak B 1 (~405 eV) was the opposite and thus a σ* character was assigned to it. Finally, peak A 1 (at ~399 eV) was ascribed to N 1 s ! π* transition of pyridinic moiety. The incorporation of nitrogen in the graphene layer is verified by the N-Kedge NEXAFS spectra where the peaks at 400.7 and 408 eV exhibit similar angular dependence with the π* and σ* peaks of the C-K-edge graphene spectra, respectively [212].
Cl doping was also investigated using C-K-edge NEXAFS. Cl, which is a p-type dopant, introduces a shoulder or a peak at approximately 0.8 eV below the π* resonance [213].
Haberer et al. studied hydrogenated graphene (H-graphene) [214]. H-graphene exhibited the expected angular dependence of the π* and σ* resonances, although the intensity of the π* resonance was slightly lower due to the formation of C-H bonds which reduced the sp 2 hybridization. The π* resonance also appeared to have a weak shoulder in its low energy part which was assigned to an electronic state in-between the π and π* states. The results were verified by tight-binding calculations. Density functional theory calculations were also performed to simulate the C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra of graphene and the effect of various defects [215]. Functionalization of graphene layers caused by 1 MeV electron irradiation was studied by K.-j. Kim et al. [216]. Irradiation resulted in a decrease of the intensity of the π* resonance and evolution of resonances at 287.2 and 288.0 eV which were attributed to C=O, i.e., irradiation resulted in oxidation of the graphene layer.
The effect of growth temperature on the structure of a few-layer graphene, grown by molecular beam epitaxy, was also investigated using C-K-edge NEXAFS [217]. More specifically, when the growth temperature was 500 C, only amorphous C was observed. For temperatures higher than 700 C, the characteristic π* and σ* resonances evolved and they became sharper upon temperature increase up to 1300 C. In addition to that, strong contribution from C-O bonds was observed. Good quality graphene layers were grown on Si, instead of Al 2 O 3 , substrates, at 800 C [218]. Graphite flakes consisting of a few graphene layers were investigated using X-ray transmission imaging at the C-K-edge. The sample was illuminated by the focused (using a capillary) quasi-monochromatic SR beam. The sample was imaged by a zone plate objective with a CCD camera and the spatial resolution was  plane" absorption that corresponds to the σ* region, and in blue the "out-of-plane" absorption, which corresponds to the π* absorption, is shown in Fig. 4.31c. The "inplane" signal is much stronger for the flat part of the graphite flake, whereas the "outof-plane" signal is stronger for the folded part of the flake. SXTM images of single layer graphene grown by chemical vapor deposition revealed local variations in the intensity of the transmitted light. C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra from different sample spots identified variations in the intensity of the π* resonance. Nonzero intensity of the π* resonance indicates the presence of folds or ripples in the graphene layer [220]. Acquisition of C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra from different spots of a graphene sample, which were preselected from photoemission electron microscopy (PEEM) images, revealed the progressive variation of the spectra with the number of graphene layers [221].
Two-dimensional graphene oxide (GO), exfoliated from oxidized graphite, exhibits a behavior similar to that of a wide-band gap semiconductor. GO-metal oxide nanocomposites are suitable materials for supercapacitor applications. Similar to the case of graphene, the NEXAFS spectra of GO exhibit angular dependence that allow for the determination of the orientation of the O-related defects which give rise to additional peaks. Resonances that appeared at 286.5, 288.7, and 289.6 eV were assigned to π* excitations of C-O, C=O, and -O-C-OH, respectively [222]. The GO spectra were not significantly affected when nanocomposite structures with MnO 2 were formed. Reduction of GO resulted in the disappearance of the peak at 289.6 eV indicating the removal of the hydroxylated species with heat treatment. Reduction resulted also in enhancement of the π* resonance intensity, stronger angular dependence, and sharpening of the peaks in the σ* region indicating that an extended and less defective network was formed. Hybrid catalysts consisting of MnCo 2 O 4 nanoparticles deposited on N-doped graphene were studied by means of XAFS at the C-and metal-absorption edges [223]. Initially, the metal precursors reacted with mildly oxidized graphene (mGO) and NH 4 OH was added to provide the necessary N dopant. Next a hydrothermal treatment step was used to reduce the N-doped mGO and to promote crystallization of the metal nanoparticles. The π* and σ* resonances of graphitic C could be clearly resolved in C-K-edge spectra of the reduced N-doped GO. However, in the corresponding spectra of hybrid catalysts, features with considerable intensity due to C=N (~287.5 eV), O-C=O (~288.5 eV), and C-OH and C-O-C (~289.5 eV) appeared, indicating bonding of O and N to metal atoms in the oxide nanoparticles. Variations were also observed in the N-Kedge NEXAFS spectra where in the hybrid catalysts, enhanced intensity of π* resonance in the range of 398-402 eV (pyridinic, pyrrolic or amino, graphitic N) was observed compared to the spectra of N-doped reduced mGO. These variations were attributed to bonding of N to metal. The authors discussed also the L 2,3 -edge spectra of Mn and Co. Sulfur-graphene oxide (S-GO) nanocomposites are promising cathode materials for rechargeable Li/S cells. They were studied by means of S-K-, O-K-, and C-Kedge NEXAFS spectra recorded after different numbers of discharge-charge cycles in order to identify variations in the S and C bonding. In the S-K-edge spectra, peaks that correspond to transitions from 1 s to final π* states could be detected. The peaks due to S-S (2472.2 eV) in elemental sulfur or C-S-S-C bonding in S-GO and due to C-S (2473.7 eV) of S-GO were identified. Acquisition of the spectra after discharge-charge cycles revealed changes that were attributed to loss of elemental S and/or S species bonded to GO, i.e., active S species, as a result of cycling as well as the presence of S 2À , SO 3 2À , and/or SO 4 2À . These products were formed at the expense of the active S species. Changes were also observed in the C-K-edge NEXAFS spectra upon cycling, with the characteristic π* and σ* peaks of graphene loosing intensity and giving place to peaks due to CO 3 2À , RO À , and -CH 2 -. The results supported the formation of lithium carbonate due to the Li/S-GO cell operation. Quantification of the variation of the different species, which could be identified from the NEXAFS spectra as a function of the discharge-charge cycle, was also provided after proper fitting of the spectra [224].
Graphene often results from the reduction of GO that can be exfoliated from oxidized graphite. Hydrothermal reduction of GO to graphene in the temperature range 120-180 C resulted in partial restoration of the sp 2 bonding and removal of oxygen-containing functional groups [225]. Thermal treatment of GO with urea was also successfully used for the doping of graphene, as it was deduced from NEXAFS measurements at the C-N-and O-K-edges [226]. A C-K-edge NEXAFS study of the reduction of GO with hydrazine hydrate and a GO-paper intercalated with dodecylamine can be found in Ref. [227]. Hydrazine reduction of GO was also studied by Dennis et al. [228]. The observed increase of the π* resonance intensity upon reduction signified improvement of the short-range order. Significant incorporation of N was observed in the form of pyridine-like and pyrrole-like moieties. Reduction of the oxygen-related species, e.g., epoxide, which can unzip the C-C bonds, took place. Epoxide and carboxyl are functional groups present on the surface of graphene that was obtained from oxidized graphite exfoliation. These groups cause electronic isolation of GO although in a number of applications, they are required since they act as anchoring sites, for example, for catalysts. SXTM images, with spatial resolution 30 nm, of GO reduced by annealing at 1050 C under Ar flow [229] were recorded with circularly polarized SR light to avoid intensity variations related to local variations in the orientation. The observed intensity variations were assigned to the number of GO layers.

Nanomaterials and the Environment
The widespread applications of nanoparticles have raised considerable concern about potentially hazardous implications related to their release in the environment. On the other hand, a number of nanomaterials find important environment-friendly applications, e.g., for the removal of toxic elements from the environment, from the drinking water, or for the dissociation of toxic compounds.

Environmental Implications of Nanomaterials
Zn-K-edge XAFS was applied in order to investigate the structural changes in ZnO nanoparticles after their release in the environment and interaction with phosphates CeO 2 nanoparticles, which are extensively used in biomedical applications, in cosmetics, as polishing materials, as well as in diesel-fuel additives, are considered toxic after their release in the environment. The biotransformation, i.e., biochemical modification by living organisms, of CeO 2 nanoparticles was studied by Zhang et al. [231]. The authors investigated the speciation of Ce in cucumber. Most of Ce in the plants accumulated in the roots, with the concentration of Ce in the leaves and stems being similar. The Ce-L 3 -edge XANES spectra recorded from the root, stem, and leaf of the cucumber plant are shown in Fig. 4.32 along with spectra of reference compounds. The double peak with components denoted by B and C is a fingerprint of Ce 4+ , whereas peak A is the characteristic of Ce 3+ . The partial reduction of Ce 4+ in the CeO 2 nanoparticles to Ce 3+ in the plant can be easily deduced from the spectra, with the Ce 3+ /Ce 4+ ratio appearing to be higher in the roots. Linear combination fitting was applied for the determination of the corresponding ratios in various parts of the plant.
Ce was found to retain the form of CeO 2 nanoparticles in soybean plants grown in CeO 2 -nanoparticle contaminated soil, while only a small amount was reduced to Ce 3+ [232]. In the same study, ZnO nanoparticles were used to contaminate the soil. It was found that Zn was bonded to O. The Zn-K-edge XANES spectra were well reproduced by a mixture of Zn nitrate and Zn citrate. In both cases, the XAFS spectra were recorded from metal-rich spots which were identified from micro-XRF maps. In a similar study on the uptake of coated CeO 2 nanoparticles by corn plants, significant reduction of Ce 4+ to Ce 3+ was not detected in the plant roots [233].
Ti-K-edge XAFS was used to study the accumulation and dissolution of TiO 2 nanoparticles, with diameters ranging from 14 to 655 nm, in wheat plants [234]. The spectra were recoded from Ti-rich plant parts which were identified from micro-XRF images. The spectrum profile and the relative intensity of the components of the pre-edge peak revealed that TiO 2 nanoparticles with anatase and rutile structures do not dissolve and retain their structure in the leaves and the roots of the plant.
Regarding the interaction of nanoparticles with tissues, Vaeronesi et al. [235] investigated the interaction of TiO 2 nanoparticles with cell cultures. More specifically, TiO 2 nanoparticles, with the structure of rutile and size of 21 nm, were incubated in gastric and intestinal fluids, to simulate the effect of gastrointestinal fluids on the structure of the nanoparticles. Micro-XRF was used for the selection of Ti-rich spots from where the XAFS spectra were recorded. Both the EXAFS and XANES spectra of the pristine nanoparticles and those internalized in the cells were similar, indicating that dissolution of the TiO 2 nanoparticles did not occur. The in vitro interaction of 7 nm CeO 2 nanoparticles with human dermal fibroblasts was also investigated and the reactions at the interface of nano-CeO 2 with the fibroblasts were studied with XAFS [236]. Partial reduction from Ce 4+ to Ce 3+ was deduced from the Ce-L 3 -edge spectra.

Nanosized Adsorbents of Toxic Elements
Nanosized metal oxides are used for the adsorption of toxic elements, for example, As from drinking water. As in natural waters exists in the form of As 3+ and As 5+ . Trivalent As is considered as more toxic. The maximum allowed concentration of As in drinking water is 10 μg/l. Nanosized absorbents appear to be more effective compared to their macro-sized counterparts due to their large surface area. The ability of the adsorbents to oxidize As 3+ to the less toxic As 5+ and the trapping mechanism of As on the surface of the nanoparticles depend on the oxidation state of As, the chemical composition of the sorbent, and the solute pH. The As-K-edge XANES spectra (Fig. 4.33a) are characterized by a very intense white line whose energy position is a fingerprint of the oxidation state of As. The As-K-edge EXAFS spectra can provide additional information on the oxidation state of As. More specifically, As exists in water in the form of oxyanions. The As-O distance in the case of As 3+ is longer compared to the corresponding distance in As 5+ . The presence of further peaks in the Fourier transform (red and blue lines in Fig. 4.33b) is the characteristic of the adsorption of the oxyanion on the surface of the absorbent forming an inner sphere complex. Various modifications have been detected as either bidentate or monodentate, binuclear or mononuclear [237]. Another study was focused on the adsorption of As 3+ on Mg(OH) 2 . In this case layered structures by AsO 3 polymer chains (Fig. 4.33b) may be formed [238].
The efficiency of amorphous TiO 2 and TiO 2 nanoparticles, obtained by calcinations, in the adsorption of As was studied by Jegadeesan et al. [239]. It was found that As 3+ oxidized to As 5+ only when TiO 2 was amorphous. EXAFS analysis revealed that both As 3+ and As 5+ formed bidentate binuclear complexes. As-Kedge EXAFS study of the adsorption of As 5+ by γ-alumina nanoparticles disclosed the formation of bidentate binuclear complexes bonded to the octahedra of the Al 2 O 3 structure [240].
The As 5+ trapping in magnetite nanoparticles was studied by means of absorption and precipitation methods [241]. In the adsorption samples, the arsenate (AsO 4 ) oxyanion was found to form bidentate binuclear complexes. In the precipitation samples and for high As 5+ loading, the results demonstrated that part of the AsO 4 tetrahedra were incorporated in the magnetite structure. The study of the trapping mechanism of As 3+ and As 5+ from green rust Fe 2þ 1Àx Fe 3þ
[242] revealed that oxidation of As 3+ did not take place. Bidentate binuclear and monodentate mononuclear complexes were detected in the case of As 5+ with the relative concentration depending on the As loading. Regarding As 3+ , it was found that As forms dimmers of arsenite pyramids (As 2 O 5 ) which are bonded to the layers of the green rust. Starch-stabilized magnetite nanoparticles were used for As 5+ adsorption [243]. Starch plays the role of stabilizer of the magnetite nanoparticles, affecting their size and surface properties. As was found to form bidentate binuclear and monodentate mononuclear complexes.
Since As 3+ is more toxic than As 5+ , processes that enhance the transformation of As 3+ to As 5+ and/or As retention are of interest for the remediation of As-contaminated groundwater. As-K-edge XANES verified the oxidation of As 3+ to As 5+ from magnetite nanoparticles in the presence of O 2 . As 3+ oxidation under similar oxic conditions was also achieved with ferrihydrite nanoparticles but only after addition of an aqueous solution of Fe 2+ [244]. Oxidation of As 5+ to As 3+ and efficient trapping may be achieved by adding Mn (preferably tetravalent) in Fe oxides/hydroxides. Tresintsi et al. [245] studied the adsorption mechanism of As 3+ and As 5+ from mixed Fe/Mn oxy-hydroxide adsorbents. The Mn-K-and As-Kedge XANES spectra revealed that the oxidation state of Mn was 4+ and As 3+ was successfully oxidized to As 5+ by the Mn ions. The EXAFS analysis demonstrated that the As oxyanions were adsorbed in the bidentate mononuclear geometry, where the AsO 4 tetrahedron shares common edge with the FeO 6 octahedra. Similar observations were reported by Zhang et al. [246] who studied Fe/Mn binary oxides (of the type MnO x -FeOOH) before and after the adsorption of As. The oxidation state of Mn was found between 3+ and 4+ and it was deduced that it efficiently oxidized As 3+ to As 5+ . The arsenate species were trapped in the form of bidentate binuclear complexes. Composite absorbents consisting of magnetite (Fe 3 O 4 ) and Mn 3 O 4 were also used for the adsorption of As 3+ [247]. The As-K-edge XANES spectra disclosed that the adsorbed As was oxidized to As 5+ , a process attributed to the presence of Mn. The Fe 3 O 4 component offered the possibility for magnetic solid/liquid separation. Another application related to the oxidation of contaminant elements by Mn-containing nanoparticles is the oxidation of Sb 3+ to Sb 5+ by manganite (γ-MnOOH) nanoparticles, as it was verified by Sb-L 3 -edge XANES [248].
Iron oxide nanoparticles have been also considered for the adsorption of other elements which are considered toxic above certain concentrations. The trapping mechanism of Se 6+ on maghemite nanoparticles was studied with XAFS measurements at the Se-K-edge [249]. Similar to the case of As-K-edge spectra, a white line is present in the XANES spectra recorded at the Se-K-edge. From the position of the white line, it was deduced that the oxidation state of Se did not change after its sorption on the maghemite nanoparticles. EXAFS analysis demonstrated that the selenate tetrahedra formed bidentate binuclear complexes with the two corners of the Fe polyhedra. Nanoparticles produced by ball milling of red mud, a residue generated during the production of Al from bauxite, were used for the study of the trapping mechanism of Cd that is another toxic element [250]. Linear combination fitting of the XANES spectra recorded at the Cd-L 3 -edge disclosed the formation of inner sphere complexes of the form XCd(OH) where X represents surface groups of the red mud.
Contamination of water resources by heavy metals, for example, Ni, Pb, and Hg, which are by-products of industrial activities, is also of great concern. Tinanate nanotubes (TNTs) were used for the removal of Ni 2+ [251]. For low interaction times, only one neighboring shell of Ni, consisting of six O atoms, was detected indicating that outer sphere complexes were formed via ion exchange with the TNTs. For higher interaction times, contribution of further shells (comprise of both Ti and Ni) was detected, indicating the formation of inner-sphere complexes and precipitates. Increase of the sorption pH promoted the formation of inner sphere complexes at lower interaction times.

7
Conclusions and Future Perspectives XAFS spectroscopy, carried out using synchrotron radiation beams with beam size that ranges from hundreds of micrometers to few tens of nanometers, is a unique tool for the study of a plethora of materials developed for nanotechnology applications. Although in most of cases the XAFS signal provides average information from a certain sample volume, it is a versatile and attractive technique because it is element specific and nondestructive; it does not rely on the long-range order, as diffraction techniques do; and it is able to obtain signal from small quantities of a variety of materials, e.g., liquids, solids, quantum structures, composites, complexes, diluted samples, and elements that span almost the whole periodic table.
The multitude of information that can be obtained is related to symmetry, electronic properties, charge transfer and oxidation state, element-specific magnetic properties, bonding configuration of elements, finite size effects and disorder, chemical effects, etc.
The development of quick-XAFS, with the improvement of acquisition electronics and detectors, offered the possibility to perform dynamical studies in the sub-second scale. The use of dispersive monochromator optics and CCD detectors permits measurements at even shorter time scales. When combined with proper sample environments for in situ characterization, unique information can be obtained on the dynamics of the material synthesis processes and the evolution of chemical reactions. Time-resolved measurements also permit the study of material response upon perturbation, for example, the application of external magnetic fields, laser light, mechanical stress, or mixing with a reactant. Time slicing is a relatively new method that offers sub-picosecond pulses of X-rays for the study of ultrafast phenomena.
Although microspectroscopy techniques enable XAFS measurements and XRF imaging of inhomogeneous samples with beam size of about 1 μm, still the size of the beam is 2-3 orders of magnitude larger than the size of nanomaterials. Toward the improvement of the spatial resolution, spectromicroscopy techniques are developed, where the XANES spectra are reconstructed from X-ray microscopy images with spatial resolution of approximately 50 nm. These images are recorded at different energies that span the XANES spectral region of the element and edge of interest.
Finally, the development of free electron lasers will improve dramatically the spatial and time resolution, thus enhancing the possibilities for advanced and intriguing XAFS-based methods for the study of nanomaterials of various kinds.  Much is still to be learned about the properties of these materials, however. At what point in cluster growth does a material change from the quantum behavior of a single atom or molecule to the ensemble behavior of a bulk metal [1]? Is the transition smooth with increasing cluster size, or is there an intermediate region where the clusters have properties that are neither metallic nor due to quantum size effects [2]? Is there a relationship between the size of the clusters and their electronic, optical, and catalytic properties [3]? Is there a correlation between structure and electronic properties [4]? How are structure and electronic properties affected by a complex environment (including different temperatures, pressures, or solvation effects) [5]? Since APNCs are the focus of this book, some answers to these questions are presented in other chapters.
However, a very brief introduction shall help the reader to understand the separation of the group of APNCs from the wider group of nanoparticles (NPs). The definition of NPs as mesoscopic systems between atoms or molecules and macroscopic bulk material can apply to a good number of structures with particle sizes of 100 nm. The term APNC means that these NPs have a precise number of atoms and generally implies that they are small (below 10 nm diameter). It is reported that the atomic precision of APNCs affects catalytic and optical properties and gives exceptional stability to the APNC (e.g., [4,[6][7][8]). A brief history of Au APNCs is given in Schaaff et al. [7].
The first step in understanding the correlation between the structure and the chemical and physical properties (which enable tailoring of the catalytic properties of the APNC [9]) is to gain precise knowledge about the structure of the clusters. X-ray diffraction (XRD) is the best method to determine the structure of a material. For APNCs, there is a certain degree of disorder [10] and fluidity [11] on the surface due to the presence of ligands. For this reason, it is mostly not possible to grow crystals and determine the structure using XRD [12]. In order to find some understanding of the structure for these cases, certain semiempirical models have been developed [13,14]. For example, "staple fitness," concerning the highest structural stability of the staple motif [15], will be discussed later in this paper.
The most basic structural models were created on the basis of atomic packing structures (e.g., fcc) and are summarized by Benfield [16]. The atomic packing mode in metal NCs is in direct correlation with their size and other structural properties [4,9,17]. Specifically, the stability stands in direct relation to the so-called magic numbers [9]. Details will be discussed further below. New approaches using density functional theory (DFT) have made it possible to determine the structures of several clusters, e.g., Au 25 (SR) 18 [18], Au 38 (SR) 24 [19], and Au 144 (SR) 60 [20]. Challenges include the determination of the cluster size (more specifically the number of atoms) from the packing mode models and the understanding why smaller clusters have icosahedral structure in one case and cuboctahedral structure in another [11].
The most studied group among the APNCs is the gold clusters (Au x (SR) y ) with thiol capping. This is because when the gold-sulfur interface can be understood (including atomic and electronic structure, properties of signal transmittance, excitations, and electron transport), then they can be applied to fields such as nanocatalysis, molecular electronics, biolabeling, photonics, and sensing [20]. Further, the extremely high surface-to-volume ratio of these gold clusters (Au x (SR) y ) can help with the understanding of self-organization processes in self-assembled monolayers (SAM) [7]. Solution phase investigations of Au clusters can reveal the physical and chemical properties of atomically precise Au nanoclusters [21]. In contrast to the use of thiol ligands is a new method of NC stabilization with s: These dendrimer-encapsulated nanoclusters (DENs) show quite different properties compared to thiol-stabilized NCs [22].
The second step in the understanding of the physical and chemical properties (specifically the catalytic properties) of APNCs is the determination of their electronic properties, which depend on the basic structure (size, packing) and environment. In particular, the size of a cluster will determine whether its electronic properties are discrete, i.e., atoms, molecules, and small clusters or form a band structure, i.e., bulk metals [4]. Common techniques to determine the electronic structure of materials are UV-vis spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (which needs ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) conditions [9]). Another procedure that is used is the calculation of density of states based on quantum chemistry [23].
The goal of the generation of APNC is not only the control of the size (e.g., number of atoms) but also the distribution of metals in the case of the bimetallic NC. The determination of the distribution of the two metals is another aspect of the concept of "active sites" which includes defects, sharp corners, and atomic steps, and its understanding can help control catalytic reactions further [6].
The electronic properties can change if the two metals are distributed in the certain way [24]. For example, alloys with Pd, Ag, Pt, or Cu based on Au 25 (SR) 18 and Au 38 (SR) 24 NC were synthesized and investigated by both theory and experiment and showed that the content and distribution of second metal (doping) have direct effects on the geometrical structure and electronic properties (e.g., [25][26][27][28]). In the cases of Au 24 Pt(SR) 18 [25], Au 24 Ag(SR) 18 [26], Au 24 Pd(SR) 18 [27,28], and Au 24 Cu(SR) 18 [29,30], the dopant atoms are believed to occupy the central site of the metal core. It is the precise knowledge of the structure and electronic properties of the NCs that is important in the understanding of the catalytic properties. To achieve this goal, methods to investigate the structure and electronic properties have to be developed constantly [31].
A powerful characterization technique for many materials is X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). XAS has become a very important tool among the synchrotronbased techniques for the characterization of materials, especially metal nanoparticles and catalysts [9,32]. Because XAS is element specific, this gives a very special opportunity to observe the same sample from different points of view if several elements, e.g., metals in alloy, are used (more details below). XAS is applicable to a broad range of elemental concentrations (i.e., from tens of ppm to wt% levels) [32] for solids and liquids as well and does not require long-range order in the sample [33]. In addition to the oxidation state, the chemical environment and geometrical information can be extracted from XAS. One aspect of XAS that especially combines theoretical and experimental techniques is extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectroscopy. The analysis of EXAFS can:
• Determine coordination numbers (CN) to the neighboring atoms in a NC • Determine distances of Me-Me and Me-L bonding • Compare structure models with experimental data • Determine structural disorder (up to a degree) These important structural details can even be extracted from amorphous materials [2]. The resolution of EXAFS regarding the bond distances is of the order of 0.001 Å within a distance of about 10 Å from the center to analyze the local structure [3]. In this respect, EXAFS can even extract structural information which is based on the atomic packing models above from systems that do not have a longrange order.
Using the other aspect of XAS, X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES, formerly called NEXAFS) spectroscopy, it is possible to:
• Analyze the electronic properties (i.e., density of electronic states above the Fermi level) • Determine the effective oxidation state • Determine the chemical speciation In this review, we focus on the methods and problems that are connected with the characterization of APNCs using XAS. Correct structural models and purity of NP content are the most important aspects to highlight. Together EXAFS and XANES are very versatile (nondestructive, study both atomic and electronic structure) and can be applied to the characterization of all kinds of materials and reactions in situ, even if they require high temperatures, high pressures, or other environmental changes, e.g., solvation and vaporization [12]. XAS techniques can be combined with theoretical calculations to validate structural models [31].
Some questions that will be answered in this review are the following:
• When was EXAFS first used for the characterization of APNC?
• How is the atomic size (numbers of atoms) determined by using EXAFS?
• What is so different in the use of EXAFS to study APNC compared to normal NP? • What is the effect of structural disorder on the EXAFS analysis technique?
• How can the electronic information contained in XANES be extracted? This latest review focuses on the use of XAS to characterize the structure, electronic properties, and behavior of APNCs, including during heating, solvation, and catalytic activity.
Other recent reviews on related topics include the following: Bare and Ressler [32] and Frenkel et al. [34] discuss the broader field of catalysis and the application of catalytic reactors together with (in situ) XAS. A more specified discussion of the catalytic activity of metal DENs using catalytic reactors investigated with in situ XAS was published by Myers et al. [22]. The wider region of the characterization of NP using XAS was reviewed by Frenkel et al. [35], Lapresta-Fernandez et al. [36], and Modrow [9].
In the wide field of applications of EXAFS, theoretical methods especially the combination of EXAFS with other theoretical methods such as density functional theory (DFT) and molecular dynamics (MD) are progressing fast and are becoming the state of the art of the characterization techniques [34]. Some of these techniques will be discussed here later to present a complete as possible overview of the techniques currently available in the XAS toolbox.
